18958594.review:
[h1]Ys Origin[/h1]

[b]Story[/b]
You follow the story of Yunica Tovah, Hugo Fact & The Claw and the events that takes place 700 years before Ys 1 and tells the back-story of Ys, Darm Tower, the Black Pearl, the twin goddesses, and the six priests.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
You have the option to play as one of two characters, a third character is playable after completing the game once with either Yunica or hugo on any difficulty level, on five different difficulty levels ranging from very easy to nightmare 
which is sure to give all types of gamers a challenge. The game can get a bit grindy at times but overall the gameplay is fast and exciting with allot of button smashing that makes you feel like you just went a round at the gym.

After you played through with all the characters I suggest you give [i]Time Attack[i] a try which is a mode where you only fight the bosses and try to beat them as fast as possible. 
The replay value of the story mode is not that great if you ask me, unless you haven't played it in a good while.

Unlike Ys 1 & 2 where you run into enemies to damage them you now have a Action/Attack button, as well as a Jump button, which is a nice change from the bump system.

[b]Sound[/b]
The soundtrack is [u]absolutely amazing[/u] which is no surprise since the Ys series always had a great soundtrack.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The graphics looks nice on newer as well as a bit older PC's and gives you that RPG feeling.

[b]Final words[/b]
All in all Ys Origin is a great game you shouldn't miss if you are a A-RPG fan.

+Boss fights are great and gets your blood pumping.
+Amazing soundtrack.
-Can get a bit grindy.

[h1]Score:[/h1] [b]8/10[/b]

18564949.review:
아루온에서 재미있게 즐겼던 추억이 있어 추억미화나 깨볼겸(?) 플레이 했으나 되려 푹 빠져들어 주말 내내 이스 오리진만 한 듯하다. 

그래픽도 완전히 3D로 넘어오기 직전이라 안습한 그래픽이 아닌, 회사의 역량 내에서는 최상으로 뽑았구나 싶은 그래픽이다. 상당히 깔끔하고 옛날 게임 특유의 지저분함이나 이질감이 거의 없다. 일러스트도 (내 기준으론) 요즘 팔콤 게임 일러스트보다 훨 낫고. 정작 나올 땐 이 일러스트 땜에 열나 까였던 기억이 나는데 난 그 때도 이 일러스트가 좋았다. 예전이나 지금이나 궤적 시리즈 일러스트가 너무 싫었기 때문에... 일단 유니카가 귀여우니 다 용서 가능 

액션도 훌륭하다. 2등신 캐릭터지만 타격감이나 시원시원함은 상당하다. 레벨디자인도 잘 되어있는 거 같다 (겜알못이라 확신은 못함). 보통 난이도 기준으로 특별한 노가다 없이도 스테이지 구석구석을 놓치지 않고 다 둘러보았다면 스킬이나 아이템 습득을 완전히 다 할 수 있고 해당 스테이지의 보스도 무리 없이 클리어할 수 있게끔 디자인 되어있다. 보스전의 경우 패턴이 조금 알기 쉽긴 하지만 적당히 재미있다.

세 가지 플레이어블 캐릭터도 각각 RPG의 클래식 직업(전사, 도적, 마법사)을 담당하고 있기 때문에 입맛대로 플레이 가능하다. 가장 기존 이스에 가까운 캐릭터는 전사인 유니카지만 근접 클래스 특성상 마법사인 유고보다는 약간 어렵다.(유고가 쉬운 것에 가깝다) 세 캐릭터 모두 다른 특수 스킬을 가지고 있는데 각 캐릭마다 좀 잉여스킬들이 있는 듯 한 건 단점.

취미로 게임 만드는 음악회사 팔콤답게 음악도 좋다. 다만 난 예전부터 배틀 음악은 별로였고 (...) 스테이지 내 곡이 좋았다. 특히 좋았던 것은 수옥의 영역. 

스토리는 이스 시리즈의 프리퀄에 해당하기 때문에 기존 이스 유저가 아니더라도 무리없이 이해 가능하다. 어차피 이스 시리즈야 악을 쳐부수는 착한 아돌과 친구들 <- 이 스토리에서 거의 벗어나지 않기 때문이기도 하지만... 오리진도 스토리는 상당히 단순하고 좀 유치한 면이 있을 수도 있지만, 그래도 오그라드는 대사와 컷씬이 "그나마" 적은 게임이라 이런 류의 일본 게임 치곤 진입장벽이 낮...을지도 (물론 이 말에 책임 지진 않습니다^^^^^) 

최대 단점은 진 엔딩을 보려면 플레이어블 3가지 캐릭터를 모두 플레이 해야 한다는 점. 물론 캐릭터마다 나름 부여된 스토리가 있어서 같은 상황도 다르게 묘사되는 장면도 있고, 세 캐릭도 나름 뚜렷하게 다른 플레이 스타일을 가지고 있긴 하지만, 거의 같은 게임을 세 번이나 해야 하는 건 좀 지루하다. 그렇다고 완전히 다른 게임 3개를 만들 수도 없으니 어쩔 수 없었겠지만. 

어쩄든 개인적으론 무척 추천작. 
난 어크같은 휘황찬란한 그래픽이거나 위쳐3처럼 스토리 개쩌는 게임 아니면 안할건데요, 하시는 분들 제외하곤 비교적 자신있게(?) 추천할 수 있을 것 같다.

18024091.review:
Excellent game.

Really, I usually find something to nitpick at, but with Ys Origin, it's darn near impossible, since it's such a solid, satisfying title.

STORYLINE: 3/5
It's got an entertaining, although kind of cliche, anime-like storyline, that's enough to keep you feeling that you're actually making progress as you play. Nothing out of ordinary here, but not bad either.

CONTROLS: 5/5
It has fantastic controls. I just finished my first playthrough and started my second one (with another character) using an xbox controller and it plays just awesome. Responsive action, simple, yet rewarding controls. Maybe that's the best part of the whole game, it sounds kind of silly, but it just feels good to control the characters as you go. In a simple sentence: the game just feels amazing on your thumbs as you play.

GRAPHICS: 4/5
Pretty cool graphics that remind me of PS1's RPG games: anime-like portraits, Ragnarok like sprites, pretty good, overall. The in game effects (such as explosions and fire) are just okay, but the cutscenes are pretty good and nicely rendered.

GAMEPLAY: 5/5
A simple, intuitive item/level system, with very few choices to make. Reminds me a little of how DMC deals with this kind of thing: you get stronger as the enemies get stronger (no choices in stats), and your weapons compose a little, but handful, arsenal, which you'll have to switch around to get through various enemies/situations. I usually like this kind of system, since it gets me more focused on the gameplay, not on the mechanics, but I do feel they could have done with a little more variety, ability wise. Still, solid system, which absolutely doesn't get frustrating as you go (i.e. no grinding absolutely required, at least on normal dificulty playthroughs).

SOUND FX and MUSIC: 3/5
Music is pretty cool too, although a bit repetitive. Sound effects are what you'd expect from this kind of game, adds to the good feeling you get from hacking at an enemy (could have used the rumble feature on a controller, though).

OVERALL:  4/5
Overall, I give this game a solid 4 out of 5 score. It's not a Steam MUST PLAY, but you definitely won't regret going through a couple of playthroughs. This game turned out to be a real diamond in the rough for me. 
Bought it years ago cheap in some sale. And thought i would play it just because it's in my library. 
Turned out this game is awesome!

It's an action RPG, hack 'n' slash style. Combat is very fluid and responsive and more importantly fun. 
The story in the game is also very good, although it develops along slowly, so it wont rope you in that fast. But once it gets it's hooks in you it's too late. This is the first Ys game i bought and after completing it i had to buy Ys I & II Chronicles+, i want to know how the story continues, and i will get the other games aswell.

The game is unique in that you have to play the game through 3 times to get the full story. There are 3 characters to play. Yunica, Hugo and Toal. Toal can only be played after you have completed the game with Yunica and Hugo, and rightfuly so as Toals playthrough contains the most story with couple plot twists even.

This game also has a very high replayability. It wont get boring to play through it several times. And after you beat the game there is also time attack mode, boss rush and arena where you can compete for leaderboards. In arena you also get points you can use in a bonus shop to buy alternative characters to play through the story with.

Big time bang for your buck!

On story page it says this game has partial controller support. I played through it with controller, also tried keyboard both works fine, i just liked controler better. Even if all tutorial popups show keyboard keybinds.

17623744.review:
[h1][list]
     [*]Note 1: This is currently being played on Nightmare difficulty. That being said, your mileage may vary on how these games compare (how easy is is to make money, gain exp, etc.)

     [*]Note 2: I will be comparing this to Oath in Felghana's gameplay. Spoilers for both games will be unmarked, so please read at your discretion. 
[/list][/h1]

     This is a review of the game from a technical/gameplay standpoint [b] not [/b] a review regarding the storyline, graphics, etc. I am writing this review for those that wish to play the Ys games in chronological order. 

     For those of you that don't know, Origin, Oath in Felghana, and Ark of Napishtim use the same engine. However, OiF and Origin were released after Ark of Napishtim, in that order, and thus were "tweaked" or "improved," rather, in terms of combat, stat growth, and money gain. Playing in chronological order means playing Origin, then Oif, then Ark, and getting used to things that might be missing, as you go through the series. 

     Now, I've played Origin all the way through on all characters on Nightmare difficulty, and the first thing to compare between Origin and Oif, is that Yunica and Adol play similarly to each other, without being exactly the same. For example, while Yunica and Adol's fire spells function identically, Yunica gets her fire magic from a sword, which does slightly more damage than her normal weapon, but swings slower. Other than that, their attack patterns are pretty similar, with Adol doing more thrusting as opposed to Yunica swinging her axe about (which makes sense, considering you don't stab with it). 

     In Origin, your dash attack has a chance of lowering the enemy's defence, including bosses. This is incredibly helpful as it can be chained into your normal combo. In OiF, you still have a dash attack, however, instead of lowering the enemy's defence, it is a quick 3-hits, that can be chained into your normal combo. That being said, in Origin, it's imperative to learn how to effectively use your dash attack, where as in OiF, you can almost completely disregard it, and get by just fine. 

     The second thing to note, OiF and Origin have a thing called Boost, which functions similar to a Limit Break, if you will; while it's active, movement and attack speed is increased, while damage is greatly reduced. However, Origin added an additional power to that, called Burst, a special attack that, when activated, will use the remaining time on your Boost. The attack varies for each character, but is nice to have, as it's essentially a panic button, to go along with your Limit Break. You don't [i] need [/i] it, but it's nice to have, in the situations where you are surrounded by enemies with 3 HP, and no way out. 

     Regarding the difficulty as a whole, of both games, Nightmare is incredibly hard, even frustrating at times, in both Origin and OiF. The difference, however, is that OiF has boss fights that are much more demanding in terms of snap decisions, timing, and reflexes, whereas the dungeons leading up to said fights, are a fun challange. Not particularly terrifying or anything. The first boss, Ellefale, is both a perfect representation of what to expect later on, as well as being a nice throwback to Ys 2, where everything died by fire. If you try to dodge her attacks too early, they will chace after you, and you'll get hit, and likewise, dodge too late, and you get hit. For a first boss, having to learn the timing right then and there is incredibly demanding, especially when you die in 2 or 3 hits. Boss fights like Gyalva and Gildias very much felt the same way, requiring precise timing, quick thinking, and not using every tool in your arsenal will cost you your life. 

     On the other hand, Origin had much harder dungeons, yet had less demanding boss fights (not to say that they aren't exactly "harder"). I found myself dying quite a bit, as trash mobs used their numbers and large attack power to hit for all I'm worth. The Water Prison has you fighting enemies that can only be destroyed with your earth power, while trying to navigate underwater, looking for more oxygen. The Silent Desert has enemies that, when you first get there, can't be permanantly killed, all the while traversing quicksand, while they come from the ground and dance around you. At times, I felt myself traversing these dungeons with a sense of caution, as the next batch of enemies, and a wrong move would be the end of me. While poor planning will also get you killed in dungeons in OiF, it felt a lot more frequent in Origin. 

     Boss fights, however, were a lot more fair. The dodging you had to do from enemy's attacks would prepare you for this moment, because a lot of the bosses have projectiles, or attacks that reach large sections of the field. Jenocres' attacks feel very much like playing a shoot 'em up, for example. Which leads to one of the more noticible changes between Origin and OiF; You see the entire battlefield, and always have eyes on the boss, at all times. During the course of the fight, lightning strikes will come down in the area where you are standing, indicated by circles on the ground. You have to keep running, until the lightning is finished chasing you. Being able to see where  Jenocres is, as well as the entire arena, while dodging attacks that reach every corner of the screen is keeps you from running into another attack, after dodging the last one. 

     This, cannot be said for OiF. With the exception of Gildias and Ellefale, you do not normally have constant sight on the boss, the entire arena, and Adol, at the same time, without keeping within a certain distance of the boss. The arena in which you fight is about the same average size as the ones in Origin, however, the camera is focused on Adol, zoomed out for the boss fight. What this means is that to see all of the boss's tells and attacks before they happen, you must keep within a certain proximity. However, the result of that is a smaller margin of error for dodging and reacting to attacks. 

     To compensate for the lack of traditional shops, Origin has a system implemented where you can buy powers, named Blessings, which allow your character active passives such as boosted ailment resistance, reduced damage from terrain, or things such as increased item drop rate. However, on Nightmare, all SP (the currency of the game) is worth 1 SP. With the occasional treasure chest giving SP, you will have just enough SP throughout the game to increase the defence on your armour, and obtain 1 to 2 extra skills, depending on what you get, and assuming you are leveling normally. The lack of shops also means that you will find all of your weapons and armour, and any items you obtain must either be found, or otherwise obtained from the story. OiF does not suffer from this, as it does use the traditional shop. You do still find weapons and armour during your escapades, however, you can also buy weapons, armour, and expendable items. Thankfully, unlike in Origin, currency in the land of Felghana is a lot easier to come by, so there is no worrying about saving for just the right moment. 

     Upgrading weapons and armour requires two things: money, and Cleria Ore. In OiF, ore comes in abundance, dropped by enemies, along with gold. Every weapon and piece of armour requires both gold, and ore to level up (stat increase), with better equipment being more expensive. Origin has simplified this process, in accordance with the shop system and/or money drop rates. Weapons are upgraded specifically with Cleria Ore, however, they are scattered throughout the game, and power up your weapon enough to last you until the next upgrade, and armour is upgraded by spending SP.

17462933.review:
With its simple 3D environments, beautiful 2d sprite characters and cheesy but epically wonderful music, YS origins reminds me of something that I’d have played on the original PlayStation or the Sega Saturn.  And I mean that as a huge compliment.

Caked in classic JRPG atmosphere, simple but lush graphics and addictive arcade style gameplay, YS Origin should yet al the buttons for JRPG fans.  You get a choice of (eventually) 3 characters, all with different playstyles,  and each character follows a different branch of the main story from a slightly different perspective, which means you’ll probably at his for 30 hours to complete all three storylines, which is just enough for this kinda game.  YS forsakes the turn-based combat of most JRPGS for an arcade-action style of button mashing mayhem.  The combat system isn’t very deep, but it’s a hell of a lot of fun in the way that something like Golden Axe or Gauntlet was in the 80s, and magical effects are really beautiful.  However, what really impressed my about YS Origin is the quality of the PC port; its got graphics options galore, has been properly adjusted for PC monitors, supports keyboard and gamepads (go with a gamepad, trust me), and it runs at a constant smooth framerate. Hopefully, Japanese developers will take notice, and this quality of port will become the norm.

Fancy a blast down nostalgia lane?  Got an itch for  an action JRPG with simple but addictive gameplay?  Give this a try.

17412714.review:
(Yes, all those hours are legit. I have played this game that much.)

This is a darn good Action RPG. It's a fast paced, simple game that just hits the sweet spot between "too long" and "too short". The game is simple enough that you basically know what to do from beginning to end, but has enough variety to make it not feel mindless. It's damn fun smacking the crap out of enemies.

Despite taking place in one location, a single 25 floor tower, the game has enough variety in its areas to keep it constantly fresh and entertaining, with new mechanics to work with and environments to traverse. It has a nice difficulty curve, with bosses that continually test your wit. If you're looking for a nice challenge, pick this game up and play it on hard. 

And its soundtrack is damn good. Seriously, go to Youtube right now and type "Ys Origin - Genesis Beyond The Beginning", and tell me it doesn't make you want to play this game. I got this for 10$ and would gladly have paid full price. It's got more than enough content and has three different protagonists with their own stories and mechanics, and it's consistently fun and challenging, while offering something for just about every type of gamer.

Сюжет в Кратце:
 Вы играете за глупого ребенка, который месит демонов на право и налево и пытается спасти каких-то ангелов.

Если не знаете английский, не покупайте игру. Некоторые моменты не пройдете, да и играть будет ЕЩЕ скучнее, что в принципе невозможно. В сети перевода еще пока что нет.

+Интересные боссы
+Интересные противники
+Неплохая механика боя (для аркады)

17010896.review:
Ys Origin is a classic Japanese RPG, with old school graphics, but which have their charm; and musics are very cool. Kinematics are made with illustrations in a manga style, allowing to tell the general story of why we are there and why it is like that. As usual in every good Japanese RPG, we have a cool bad guy, with long and brilliant hair, which wants to control the world of Ys for a random reason, and which has some underlings in order to stand in your way.

The game takes place completely in a tower, we climb gradually its levels, by exploring every floor, collecting what we find as equipment and killing everything we can, jumping from time to time on platforms to move forward. At the end of every level, we have a boss to explode. There are 6 levels, each one has around 3 floors, and every level has its universe (fire, water, sand…). Yes because there are completely aquatic floors. In a tower. And above, there is a lava world. And also a forest. Yes. In a tower. A TOWER. :D

As a consequence, we adapt our fighting techniques to every level. For example thunder is very effective on the aquatic monsters, whereas fire will be effective against plants. Hello, Pokemon players!

There are several difficulties, it goes from Very Easy to Nightmare. YS Origin will take about ten hours to finish with a first character.

About characters, we have the choice between a knight girl and a magician boy. The first is a specialist of hand to hand fights, with special techniques in short and medium-range, the other one is a specialist of remote fight. Besides the difference of gameplay, every character has its own nature and background. This will influence a bit the global scenario, but the final goal won’t change: prevent the bad guy with nice hair from destroying the world. In other words. So big potential of replaying, in spite of the repetitive aspect of the game, especially because a third character is unlocked in the end of the game, as well as the bonus games like Time Attack mode or Arena, to kill a lot of monsters in a limited time.

Conclusion: a good RPG as Japaneses know how to make it, with a manga universe both in graphics and musics. The gameplay brings nothing innovative but is very pleasant. Can be rather repetitive in the long run.

16942218.review:
This is certainly an interesting game, it starts a little slow and just throws you in but thats pretty standard for a JRPG or a Hack n slash game. 

Now the combat has three styles depending on the charecter that you are using, the first uses an axe and physical skills, three skills and each of those skills have charge ups depending on how much power you which to throw at the bad guys. The second charecter is a little slower but they can use magic, its pretty much the same but different ranges/speed/damage etc. The third charecter is a secret you will have to find that yourself because its a spoiler if I tell you. Expect the gameplay to be vastly different for each of these charecters, you can also get various varients of the charecters which changes the way it all plays out.

The artstyle is pretty old fashioned, its immersive though so it doesnt really matter. In the various dungeons that you are in you will find various artstyles depending on what theme that area is going for. Its pretty cool and the soundtrack that goes with it helps a lot.

Onto music which we touched on before, at the start you would think that its a little cookie cutter but after a while you understand that the music goes with the various themes and the emotions of the game. For this reason they seem to compliment eachother very well and it sort of amplifies the emotions that you feel throughout the game. 

Storyline of this game isnt the most complex one ever id say, that being said ive only done a singe playthrough and its designed for you to play the three charecters because they each have different viewpoints in the story, they each lead to the same point but you will have to face various challenges to get to your end goal. At some points you will question what your protagonist is thinking or what their motivations are. Its well thoughtout id say but the introduction into the game was a little poor. As i understand this is the first in the series so i imagine it is meant to lay down a good foundation to the rest of the series so think of it as a prologue, a very long prologue. Its about 10-12 hours to finish the story for a single person, i imagine its the same or faster with the others.

Difficulty, this is the meat of the game because holy hell is it hard. Just go into the discussions and you will witness the poor souls that have come close to throwing all sorts of hardware out the window, at the wall or at a sibling due to how hard this can get especially the bosses. The normal difficulty of this game is hard, the easy difficulty of this game is challenging, hell even in very easy you will struggle at times. Its not for the faint of heart but that is a good thing because its pretty rare to get a fleshed out game with those sorts of scenarios anymore. It also leads to the 400+ types of monsters that you will occur, some are strong, some are weak, some resist fire, some arent. You will encounter all sorts of rabble but they all want to kill you. 

In the end this is a game that i can recommend to anyone, if you dont want to break anything then play on very easy and then work your way up, it certainly is addictive and you get one hell of a euphoria after you beat what seemed like an unbeatable boss at first(looking at you mantid)

16886829.review:
Good combat and a fair story are the strong points of this game.
Extremely linear progression and the fact that you are confined to a tower for pretty much all of the play are it's cons.

You play as three characters (a playthrough for each, one being unlockable after finishing with one of the other two) through the story mode to unravel their story as they ascend the demon tower, battling monsters and large bosses along the way. The story itself is fair, with some expected plot twists (and some not so expected) but doesn't have that much in the funny side. Everyone seems more into serious business mode. So if you want something with laughs this isn't really the game.

Combat is real time, meaning that for the most part your skill at dodging attacks will determine your success, mostly in the harder difficulties. You don't get healing items nor healing magic either but some enemies drop use-on-pickup items. Some heal, some boost a stat for a time, and there's also currency drops you use to buy upgrades. A gripe I have is that the items and currency are dropped pretty much everywhere when killing monsters and because they disappear over time, you sometimes have to choose between clearing the room or pausing to run around to grab the spread items. Each character has basic attacks, including jump and jump attacks, and obtain magic items through the game that allow them to use special abilities used mainly for battle but are sometimes needed to get past certain parts of the game. There's no puzzles here either so most of the time you are either in combat or reading the story.

Speaking of sounds, there's no voice acting here and the music is pretty much midi based. In fact all sounds remind me of the final 16 bit (SuperNES) to early 32 bit (PS1) era games so don't expect a John Williams score here.

Visuals are the same. Characters and common enemies are all sprite based(they do have beautiful portraits), while the stage and bosses use very low polygon models, akin to PSP games. Sprites are drawn in the chibi style while portraits use the usual serious anime way. The one complain I have about the visuals is that the whole game takes place in a tower where all rooms are similar in terms of textures and such, only changing their color every few stages. Sure, no room is the same and there's plenty of enemies to get you busy, but I myself like variety of backdrops and open spaces. Then again hard to do when the premise of the game is to explore a big round demon tower.

Overall it's a good game I can recommend to throw yourself back with a simple yet effective gameplay, simple visuals that while similar, don't completely bore in my opinion, and a good story to boot.

16523990.review:
I'm doing an Ys marathon, except for Celceta which I have yet to get and 7 which I'm still playing, this is my favorite gameplay wise. The story's ok and explains Ys' history well before the events of 1 and 2. While Yunica's story is ok and Hugo's was intruiging, The Claw's ending is the only one that's canon. Gameplay wise you get 3 different playstyles. 

*Yunica uses an axe [spoiler]and later a sword[/spoiler] as her main weapons, she can be a bit challenging since she's not the fastest character around but she's also a bit of a tank so you can muscle your way out of enemies with little damage. 
*Hugo's my favorite and the game just turns into a semi-bullet hell shooter. He shoots pretty fast and you will get upgrades along the way that will increase your projectiles for a duration. He's a mage so the typical low health, crazy magic damage applies to him . His shooting range is enough to be able to shoot enemies from afar.
*The Claw plays as a hack and slasher. He's a good balance of health and strength and he has a nifty transformation that's fun. [spoiler]do a boost attack then talk to the Roos[/spoiler]

After you're done with the story, you also get Boss Rush mode and a bonus shop to use for a new game. There's nothing new in the story after but if you're a completionist and/or would like to clear all difficulty, you'll find much replayability in this game. I'm currently easing myself starting from very easy until I can tackle Nightmare without ragequitting.

16518055.review: 기존 시리즈를 플레이한 사람이라면 곳곳에서 본 것 같은 이름들이 가득하고, 지금까지 알지 못했던 배경 이야기를 알게되는 재미도 있습니다. 그러나 기존 팬이 아니거나 파고들기 플레이를 좋아하지 않는 유저에겐 발매시기(2006년)를 감안해도 무던한  이 게임을 추천하기는 어렵습니다. 우선 이 게임보다 몇년씩 일찍 발매되었던 라그나로크 온라인이나 악튜러스 느낌이 나는 그래픽은 뭐 다른 장점들로 상쇄한다고 해도 삼지선다 스킬샷/평타로 이루어진 공격 시스템에 조합 요소가 부족해 단조로운 편입니다. 시리즈의 장점이던 보스전 택틱도 서로의 턴이 오고 가며 공방전을 펼친다기보단 보스와 플레이어가 일단 떨어져서 서로 할 거 하면서 그 사이에 장거리 공격을 누르고 있는 느낌으로 진행한 게 더 많았던 것 같습니다. 노말 난이도로 플레이했고 공략대로 최단 루트로만 움직인 것도 아니었는데 레벨에 따른 스탯 차이가 현저한 시스템 덕에 보스전을 3트쯤 해보고 이상하게 한번씩 스치는게 많이 아프다 싶으면 더 헤딩할 시간에 레벨 하나 올리고 오면 깨는 경우가 잦았고 이는 몰입도를 떨어뜨리는 요소였습니다. 다회차 요소가 풍부하다고 하는데 필드 및 대부분의 보스는 똑같지만 이야기의 줄기가 공식 루트로 바뀌는 진엔딩 개념이라 정확히 표현하면 1회차 플레이가 캐릭터 언락을 위한 것에 불과하다는 느낌입니다. 요약하자면 나쁜 게임은 아니지만 새롭거나 특별한 면은 없어요.

16489316.review:
This game is anime as hell, with horrible pacing, painfully awkward(ly translated?) writing, cringeworthy story, setting and characters that it shoves in your face in lengthy, unskippable conversations and cutscenes.

You should still totally play it, because once all that stuff takes a break this game is an addictively fun simple brawler with a limited but very satisfying moveset, basic but enjoyable rpg systems and very challenging (depending on your level and difficulty), varied and interesting boss fights - all supported with a catchy soundtrack.

Don't expect Dark Souls though: if any encounter is too rough - likely because you're underleveled - it usually can be trivialized by grinding a room full of enemies for 15-30 minutes to get a handful of levels over the boss. There's also easier difficulties to pick if you don't feel like "powerleveling".

The regular playthrough is a very decent length already, and the game is designed for multiple playthroughs with different characters with different abilities and boss encounters, so if you enjoy the gameplay the game certainly delivers tons of it.

16483722.review:
Well Holy Shit!
I bought this game one boring winter break with money from the holidays thinking "Aw, what the hell? It's cheap and has pretty good reviews." Turns out this game was much more fun (And difficult) Than i would have ever thought. The plot is fairly simple and easy to follow, but it's still there. I loved the music (especially the song that play's after the encounter in the mirror room.) and it changed on every floor of the tower, cycling through all sorts of various tunes and styles. The controls felt smooth (At least when playing as Yunica, I don't know about hugo) and it was especially nice to move around with dash/ double jump. But i think the best part of Ys:Origin is the boss fights. Most enemies will fight, and while their no pushovers, they go down pretty easy. But the boss's, damn are they angry. The one I remember giving me the most trouble was the end boss of the Guilty Fire segment. so many hours went in to beating that guy. but all of the boss's give trouble, keeping you in the heat of the action every time you think you've figured them out.
This is the first game I've played in the YS series, and i had no trouble figuring out who went where and what was when, I Highly reccomend this game to people who enjoy quick, smooth combat and challenging bossfights with a wide varity of music!

16479468.review:
Great game.  3 story characters to play as. (You need to unlock one). While they all tranverse the same levels they have a few differences in bosses but mostly story wise. They also each play differently. One weilds an axe, one is a mage, and the unlockable is a berserker.

Spoiler:
[spoiler] Toal, the unlockable chraracter, is the character with the canon storyline and true final boss. 	[/spoiler]

That said I felt the game had a great story and very worth its price, and with each character getting their own storyline it gives you a reason to play them all. Difficultly ranges from Very Easy to Nightmare. Upgradable skills/traits. You have to find your gear upgrades there is no shop to buy them from. Fear not since the gear upgrades are either in chest or given to you. No RNG luck based element to make you spend your days grinding instead of playing.

Bosses have gimmicks but they also for the most part seem to follow a pattern. Though the gimmicks each boss have can be enough to prevent you from winning on your first encounter with them, and 2nd, maybe 3rd. This isn't a bad thing. It requires you to actually learn how the boss works if you want to beat them instead of just brute forcing it.

That said I would just like to point out a couple of cons.

1. Keyboard controls for the most part are fluent but on a certain boss they are a bit chunky.

2. The same above applies to trying to fight flying enemies. I would suggest a gamepad if you have one.

That said I am a keyboard player and still find it around 95% fluent. Perfectly acceptable.

16413630.review:
A really enjoyable somewhat short RPG( with good multiple character replayability value). The dialog can be cheesy at time but it's enjoyable and overall story is nice, even if you haven't played any of the YS games, everything is explain to you and I think it's good starting point to actually go play YSI&II after this. After this game I fell in love with the whole series and had fun with every single one of the games in it.

The gameplay is fast paced arcade hack&shoot and can actually be pretty challenging at harder difficulties and the bosses can be pretty hard to beat, requiring you to die over and over again :P ( so it's pretty nice old school level of difficult ) The Rpg element is kinda no existent.You follow linear path of progression where your character at a lv you only get small stats increase. And the new skills are only learned thou the story when specific items are found, so it's the other equipment. There is NO random loot drop and skill choice. So when you get a new item you'd definitely feel yourself more powerful than before, becoming an unstoppable god of death... until the next area were everything you dare to look will kindly smack your butt :D

 The visuals are nice on the eye if you like animu art style(thou I wish the camera had one more level of zoom out) and the OST is simple amazing, if you doubt that simply listen to the beautiful sequence.

16092430.review:
Японская Action RPG серия Ys уходит корнями аж в восьмидесятые годы прошлого века. Origin фактически не является первой игрой в серии, но вот хронологически это как раз начало истории, приквел, так сказать. Если вкратце описывать геймплей, то игра представляет собой этакую дьяблу на японский манер. По части геймплея игра весьма хороша! Чувствуется, что игровой процесс отполирован настолько, насколько это возможно. В Origin нет ничего лишнего. В основном, игра состоит из скоротечных битв с оппонентами, населяющими уровни. Ys Origin можно порекомендовать всем, кто любит качественные и аддиктивные игры: много времени на прохождение она не требует, зато удовольствия приносит массу.

15988813.review: The 3D Y´s game with probably the best gameplay of them all. All characters are different and alot of fun to play. The only thing I can complain about is the lack of a proper overworld but that doesnt change the fact that this is a fantastic game!

15987417.review: Another great game in the Ys series! :D

15936641.review:
I was given the idea to play Ys Origin by a streamer I watched and a friend I often speak to who had nothing but praises for this franchise. When I first picked up this game I had my doubts and I wasn't entirely sure if I was going to enjoy playing it or not. I was dead wrong. 

Ys Origin is quite the amazing game, I have finished the game on two different difficulties with two of the characters and doing a nightmare playthrough on the 3rd. Even on Nightmare this game is still fresh and challenging, i've spent my time streaming this game a lot longer than I usually stream, upwards to 8 hours from my usual 5 hours and I don't want to put it down. 

The story itself can be a bit difficult to follow if you haven't played any of the other games but it's a enjoyable experience itself. The combat in the game is superb and the bosses equally so, there are some minor annoyances but the game outshines them completely. I would recommend getting this game if you're a fan of great combat and RPGs. 10/10.

15892289.review:
Ys Origin is another classic in the series that welcomes newcomers and veterans. I found t interesting that Darm Tower was the main focus in setting, I really liked exploring around in Ys I & II, but regardless, it makes up with lots of great challenges, especially if you dare tackle Nightmare mode.

You get to play multiple characters in the game, starting with 2, then unlocking a new one after you finish the game, and some cool modes if you crave for more Ys Origin action. The story is well written and kept me interested through the end. I highly recommend this to Ys fans, JRPG fans and for those who are brand new to the genre. It is another classic in the Ys series.

15876592.review:
Ys Origin se passa 700 anos antes do primeiro jogo da série Ys, sendo sem amarras cronológicas e bastante adequado para quem nunca jogou outro game da franquia.

O gameplay segue o modelo action RPG plataforma clássico, de modo ao objetivo ser subir até o último andar da Torre e ir enfrentando seus desafios até finalizá-lo. Para isso é disponível 3 personagens: uma guerreira, um mago, e um ninja. Todos com habilidades próprias, e apresentando perspectivas diferentes da historia.

Por fala na historia, ela é muito boa, recheada de personagens carismáticos e diálogos bem escritos. É a velha qualidade dos jogos da Falcom. Quem conhece, já sabe.

Por fim, o jogo possui 3 finais diferentes, sendo o verdadeiro na jornada do Ninja (The Claw). Contudo, para ele ser disponível é necessário terminar o jogo ao menos uma vez com um dos outros dois personagens. 

Altamente recomendado.

The good: Good controls, good boss fights, and nice game play.

The bad: It feels as a very linear game. No discovery, could not explore anything. No side quests. Everything is happening inside a tower. I was hoping I could find a city or a town and do some exploring but none of that exists.  

If you like a linear story, then you might like this game.

15808673.review:
Un juego muy sencillo graficamente pero con unos detalles muy desatacables, a eso me refiero con los colores utilizados en los ataques de los personajes principales y los acabados de los jefes de cada piso.

Es una experiencia muy completa, narra muy bien el inicio de la saga Y's explicando de una forma sencilla y sin mucho rodeo que sucede antes de los primeros juegos. Es un juego muy frenético, porque los combates son en tiempo real y los elementos RPG aunque pocos son interesantes para ver la prograsión que posee tu personaje en cuanto a incremento de poder y nuevos ataques.

Posee una muy buena motivación para subir de nivel y a la vez buscar todo el equipo que se encuentra por toda la torre, ya que si no se hace, el juego se vuelve bastante complicado de avanzar. Posee una rejugabilidad muy destacada por el hecho de que cuando se pasa por primera vez quedan varios personajes más, estos cambian un poco el rumbo de la historia y a su vez aumentan la dificultad del juego por la clase que poseen.

En mi caso jugué este antes que otros juegos de la saga y fue la mejor manera de comenzar en este gran mundo de Y's.

15797904.review:
이스 간판 캐릭터 아돌이 빠진 700년 전의 이스 이야기를 다룬 프리퀄 시리즈.

원거리 캐릭터와 근거리 캐릭터. 또 한 캐릭터를 클리어하면 악의 측에 서서 또 다른 진실을 마주해볼 수 있는 새로운 캐릭터가 해제된다는 점

다양한 바리에이션을 즐길 수 있다는 점이 이스 오리진의 가장 큰 매력이 아닐까 싶다.

사실 이러한 류의 액션 RPG가 각 캐릭터의 성능에 따라 난이도가 천차만별인 경우가 있지만 대개 느낀 바로는 적절하지 않았나 싶다. 초보자들이 하기 쉬운 유고 팩트나 어느정도 숙련되면 유니카로 넘어가는 식의... 뭐 상급자용 캐릭터라는 해금캐릭터 토르 팩트가 생각보다 성능이 뛰어나 유니카랑 도긴개긴이였던 점은 참.

뭐 어찌되었건 기존의 이스 이야기로 이어지는 점과 모든 흑막이 누구였는지 충격적인 진실이 밝혀지는 점 등등 원작을 즐겨하던 사람들도 파고들 요소가 있으니 참으로 좋은 게임이 아닌가 싶다.

15735090.review:
After playing Ys I and II, how I think of this game is much different. It drags along Ys I and II's coattails too much at times, so this hampers the story mode (recycled puzzles from those games, to name a few). Also there are a ton of unskippable cutscenes so it makes the multiple playthroughs required to get everything tiring.
The gameplay is good aside from horrendous imbalance between characters (bosses were not balanced around multiple characters very well, so the worst character in the game will have loads of trouble against a boss that can easily be defeated with the "better" characters). 
Soundtrack is pretty great. 

8/10
Go play Oath in Felghana or Ark of Napishtim for a better Ys experience.

The gameplay was wonderful, honestly I would change a thing about it. Yunica moves where you want, attacks where you want, slaughters thousands of enemies in an effort to grind levels, the way you want... and umm hmm I'll talk about that pretty soon. The visual style was really good to look at with a SNES era feel to it. Although, same of the 3D environments looked a little choppy and jagged it was enough to take away from the game. I liked the good use of colour throughout the games many different environments. What I found really neat that despite the fact you spend the entire game inside a tower the developers still put floors dedicated to elements such as desert, water and lava. My favourite part of the game was hands down the combat which was a pleasure to utilize. The boss fights were always overwhelming and in general were very unique. On the other hand there are some areas for improvement that I feel should be touched on. I'm not providing any plot spoilers but I do think the story was all anything to special. Ys is a great series in general and you won't be disappointed with this game. It's the 8th game from the series. It's only available on Pc and it's a prequel of Ys I & II. (So it's better to play Ys I & II to understand a bit more.)

So first of all, I just want to add that I have around 120 hours on this game and I didn't finish entirely. (I'm finishing the third character at Nightmare Mode and I'm focusing to get every achievements. Not an easy thing to do.) 

Pros:
-The story is great. (You will get the point of view on each character.)
-4 difficulties (Easy, Normal, Hard and Nightmare)
-Music is so great.
-Fast paced game. 
-Button mashing game.
-Anime game
-Time attack/Survival mode

Cons:
-Nightmare mode can be a pain in the ass. You really need to focus on farming a lot of level and to know every pattern of each bosses. You will restart a lot of them and yes, you will want to throw you controller at your screen a lot of times.
-Only two characters (a third one can be unlocked. But if you only play only one time with Yunica or Hugo, you won't be able to unlocked it.)
-The "real" story is with the third character. So people who don't love to play the same game over and over won't be able to taste it. (You need to complete the game with Yunica and Hugo, that's it.)
-Maybe overpriced if you only play one time and at easy mode. (Approximately 4-5 hours if you know what to do.)

Note 9/10 because this game has made me a fan of Ys.

Edit : If you want more information about the order that you need to play the game, check this link : http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=552476829

Ok, to put in perspective how good this game is, I was recommended this game by a friend and within the weekend I ended up beating it with all three characters.  Within a month I had played every Ys game on Steam.  After a while I ended up playing every localized Ys game and eventually I even played the fan translated Ys V.  This series is that good.  This game is like a gateway drug, only instead of being a gateway drug to something worse, it's like upgrading from sex to wild orgies with beautiful women.  

This game controls like a dream, looks gorgeous on high settings, and is just challenging enough to feel like a real accomplishment when you progress.  If you love action RPGs, you owe it to yourself to play it.  Just remember, you're getting yourself into a beautiful addiction that you won't be able to stop.

14700695.review:
After playing Ys I + 2, and Ys: Oath in Felghana, I had high expectations for this one. They were met and exceeded.

* Great music 
* Great gameplay - boss fights are amazing, and beating a boss on the higher difficulty settings is really satisfying
* Responsive controls - if you fail at the game, it's on you, not the controller
* Three different characters to play as, with different styles and viewpoints of the game's events
* Difficulty options are appreciated. I did a hard playthrough and a couple of easy playthoughs because I was a little more interested in story things than brutal gameplay

I'll probably come back to this one later for a nightmare difficulty playthrough. Or three.

Only real downside is the game setting and pacing is pretty much the same for all of the characters, so the third playthrough started to wear on me a bit. In hindsight, I shouldn't have played through it 3x without any other games mixed in to keep things fresh.

Nice Bonus - the .ogg files work with my mp3 player, unlike Oath of Felghana's.

14637133.review:
Геймплей 
Ys Origin есть три персонажа с различными стилями боя. Yunica может владеть топоры и greatswords с легкостью. В дополнение к стандартным рубить и слэш комбо, Yunica также может выполнять различные воздушные маневры, такие как вниз тяги и до тяги от предыдущих Ys игр, а также нанесения вреда нападения выпад. Уго Факт может стрелять энергию из его палочки и его «глазами Факт", так, что он может часто заполняют экран с разрушительной силой, косит всех врагов на своем пути, прежде чем у них есть шанс получить в любом месте рядом с ним. С хорошим временем, он может снять сокрушительный "Power Shot", генерации изнурительных столб чистой магии с более широкой области воздействия. "Коготь" является малой дальности / высокая характер повреждения направлены на более опытных игроков. 

Все игровых персонажей есть "Поддержка Meter", которая медленно наполняет как игра прогрессирует. После того, как этот прибор достиг мощности, что персонаж может быть временно "Повышенный" для более быстрых и сильных атак и гораздо более обороны. После того, как определенные условия были достигнуты во время игры, чему символы могут использовать специальное движение под названием "Взрыв", который быстро истощает их метр импульс в пользу ультра-мощный, чрезвычайно широкий диапазон выброса высокотоксичных разрушительной энергии.

Overall: A linear adventure from the Ys history books that, despite taking place in one buliding, has a good deal of visual variety and some strong chracter beats in its otherwise-short running time.  

Pros:Two characters (with an unlockable third) each with different perspectives on the cutscenes and different playing styles.  Each level looks and feels markedly different from the others, no mean feat in a tower-based game.  Some truly fantastic music every step of the way.  The play control is smooth and seamless whether running, jumping, or fighting.  The short length makes multiple playthroughs easier (and recommended, as the unlockable chracter gives great insights onto the bigger story).

Rating: **** / *****

14476398.review:
Fans of the Ys Series, rejoice in learning the origin of the legends which the first two games are based off of. The game primarily revolves around either Yunica Tovah or Hugo Fact, and yes, those family names should be familiar to those who've played the first two games. Each of them plays differently, with some mechanics making some fights a lot easier than others, some more difficult.

This game serves as the seventh canonical entry in the Ys series (Ys V is non-canon), and as a prequel to the entire series. It does a lot to explain a lot of the lore in the first two games, as well as why even in the main series, there is always a seemingly world ending threat around the corner.

The game has three characters, two of which are available from the start: Yunica Tovah and Hugo Fact. The third is unlockable after beating the game with either one and finishes the story with its true ending. Even if you don't beat it with him, there is still a lot that is canon from Yunica and Hugo's endings, just not the true mastermind, a very familiar enemy who was responsible for the events in Ys I & II.

Killing normal enemies is rather easy, and if you are having trouble, go back to a previous zone and grind a couple of levels, then come back. You will easily know when you've grinded enough in a zone when the experience rewards vs. the amount needed to level becomes more grindy than the time needed is worth. Basically, if you need to level, you can gain   a level in about 10 - 15 minutes, sooner if you're on the low side for the zone.

Still, the main focus is the bosses. Each has unique mechanics and weaknesses that you need to take into account. Don't be surprised if you die a few times figuring out the boss, and if your attention slips, or you make a wrong move, then you are in for a world of hurt. That's where the fun is.

14347758.review:
Ys Origin is an isometric rpg game that plays like a game you would see in the arcades very action oriented and fluid. in Ys you play as one of three selectable characters and go through their journey in order to help the goddesses fight off evil that dwells within the tower. Each character has their own dialogue and conflicts most notably the secret third character has a lot more bosses than the other two. 	

[h1]Progression[/h1]

+Statues offer instant traveling back and forth
+Enemies are highlighted red to progress
+Grinding is minimum (10-15 minutes if you're underleveled)

Traveling from floor to floor can take some time, luckily you have goddess statues that teleport you instantly to other statues you have unlocked along your travels in the giant tower. This allows the player to be able to teleport to any floor he thinks requires more exploring weather its to grab a item he missed or simply to teleport back to floor 1 for upgrades. Not only that but you are fully healed when in range of the goddess statue, you can also save.

There is practically no grinding in this game if you do not skip mobs, even if you were somehow still underleveled its relatively quick to level to the proper tier for the boss. Grinding is not required in order to defeat bosses, it can be beneficial in order to survive more hits but dealing more damage only works on anything under the highest difficulty. Being on nightmare there is set amount of damage you are going to be able to do against any bosses. This is to keep the game challenging for the purpose of the difficulty mode so that players won’t find a easy way to accomplish the feat.

Red highlighted enemies are triggers to progress through the levels. For example killing a red highlighted knight can trigger a jumping platform so you can reach a certain area otherwise unavailable. 

[h1]Level Design[/h1]

+Nice variety of environments

Despite the entire game taking place in a giant tower there is a surprising variety of environments and design with their own elements that seperate how you proceed through them. 

There is platforming but it never really gets too complicated to the point where you're constantly backtracking because you cannot perform the required jumps, its especially gets easier once you get helpful power ups like double jump.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]

+Multiple obstacles throughout the game solved with unique items
-Cinematics can interrupt your movement (Very Rare)

Going through the game you will find yourself often unable to past an obstacle that requires you to have a special item in order to proceed to the next floor. For example the item that helps with magic resistance will be useful for resisting the pull of statues trying to drag you down into a trap that sets you back to another floor and further away from your goal. 

Cinematics interrupt your movement if you happen to be above a trap for example in water when you trigger a cinematic you will fall into the spike trap and take damage when you're able to move again

[h1]Game Modes[/h1]

+Nice leaderboards (keeps track of alot of variables/characters)

Upon beating the game you will unlock more content for example the first time I beat it with Mittens, I unlocked time attack which features a circuit of going through all the bosses you fought throughout the game with set equipment and having to race the leaderboards in order to pass your friends. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

YS origin feels like one of those old very challenging arcade games with rpg elements and some platforming. The features a nice variety of boss types, even more bosses can be discovered by playing the other characters which gives the game more replayability. The game lasts around 12 hours per playthrough and with 3 characters thats a good chunk of time not to mention you have extras to go through.

14345320.review:
Well, this be my first review... Dunno how to format it but i'll try my best

Story: The game has 2 normal endings but 1 true ending, giving 3 in total. While they of course vary, there are many things which stay the same in the story such as how each character progresses. At points this makes you believe you already know all the story and what's going on after one play through, but later on the story can completely take a twist for each character. Each story does start off pretty slow, especially if you go in without any prior knowledge to the Ys series, but once the plot thickens, it thickens good. It is pretty engaging and most the characters are quite understandable and likeable.

Gameplay: I suggest you play the demo itself. On higher difficulties it can be fast paced, manic, epic and overall very enjoyable. There are a few moments in the game mind you where it can be frustrating trying to defeat a boss or enemy, because some of them are just soo cruel on the insane difficulty!.. Each character have 3 abilites they unlock through the game, each of them have their special uses for puzzle solving but also for combat, the main problem I find is that you unlock these all of these three abilites around half way, leaving not much else to unlock except for one super move or a sort per character (Which is awesome but missable) and passive abilities.

One thing which did annoy me a lot though is how vague the game could be with it's in-game instructions. For example - if you play as Yunica the game will tell you about how you can use a descending jump attack, what it DOESN'T tell you until later, after soo many chances where it could have been useful, is that the attack is capable of stunning enemies, but since the attack does little damage alone you will probably spend a lot of time playing the game without knowing this gameplay element. Neither does the game explain thrusting or how the boost meter charges quicker when you have less health (Which is really essential to know for a certain task otherwise you could be waiting about for a good 30 minutes). Now, honest maybe it did explain some of these things in the game, but if it did, it obviously didn't make it's point since i'd completed the game twice without knowing some features...

Visuals and Audio: Uh... Well this is a sorta old-ish game now, so the visuals aren't all that great for the 3D? models. Weirdly though I find the special effect in game to still look top notch, flashy and cool. The audio is fine really, I haven't much comments on it except that the OST is pretty epic and great, especially nearer to the end of the game.

Overall: Since you can, I suggest you just play the demo first, it's a great game in pretty much everyway, there are a few moments which will make you pull out your hair but otherwise the experience as a whole is brilliant for the price.
[b]8/10[/b]

-Has no real replayability once you have seen all the stories after the third playthrough. Time attack, and arena do not count since you only unlock slightly modified versions of the characters.
-If you are trying to get on the leaderboards, don't, it is littered with obvious cheaters.
-Controls will sometimes stick causing a death.
-The large delays on all actions will bring about alot of uneccessary hits.
-game will sometimes speed up.

Pros:
-Very fluid gameplay aside from above.
-Leveling system that allows for challenge playthroughs. Prepare to rip your hair out.
-Difficulty levels ranging from the "I'm new to this genre" to "Lets get right to banging my head on the wall". Bosses gain new skills, hp, and defense for every difficulty.
-3 possible stories with only one being canon for the series. Each one giving unique insights into the type of person each character is.
-Schoolgirl outfit.
-Graphics are average.

14317838.review:
Even with its focus on Dungeon Action/Platforming, YsO is by far my favorite adventure game and story amongst Falcom's lineup currently on steam.  The dialogue and localization is fantastically written, realistic, and invests you into characters without spoon-feeding you or succumbing to many of the usual JRPG tropes.  The game is challenging at appropriate difficulties, and like all of Falcom's games, changes the way bosses fight instead of just increasing their damage like a lot of other games boringly do.  The music is also a given if you know anything about Falcom and the in-house JDK band.

Potential drawbacks do include having to go through multiple playthroughs in order to get the complete story out of the game, but each character's strengths/weaknesses are different enough to provide a much different gameplay experience in addition to the altered story perspective.  The game is also fairly short to where you could probably finish the game within 10 hours on the lower difficulties without issue if you rush, but the quality makes up for it.

By far the most satisfying game I 100%'d on steam.

14042140.review:
J-Just.... THE EMERSION! A game that, to me, gave a really good bonding experience with the playable characters. Good difficulty and balance, yet still the possibility to easily gain some more fighting strength for tough fights. 

Not many games do, but this game gave me that empty feeling of sadness when it was over. I was forced to consider what just occured, and the meaning of it. And let me tell you, my conclusion wasn't a happy one. Knowing that your character was done and that you would never again experience the same thing is not very pleasant in this case. This is something I rarely see in the modern gaming genres. I want to mention a couple of things to those who have doubts about this game.

It's a japanese game, so it does have some anime-esk cut-scenes and images. Yet, these occur very rarely, so do not be concerned if you think this would bother you (Though, seriously, why would it?).

 It's an old game, don't look for good graphics and such. Though, that's not what you primarily should be looking for in a game. 

The gameplay feels smooth and fast-paced, something that I thoroughly enjoyed. Characters that are extremely unique and different from one another. Discovering the plot feels utterly fantastic. Any time something plot-related occured in between my beat up sequences, I couldn't help but let my excitement lead me through the dialogues. Remember when I mentioned I felt really empty and sad about my character that I played? How I wasn't going to be able to see her anymore? Well, that happened with not only that one, but some NPCs as well. Definitely an achievement.

Something more about difficulty. The game has 5 difficulty settings, two above and below normal. This makes it very suitable for people of all skill levels or interests. Keep in mind that you cannot change your difficulty throughout the game, yet this is also not necessary as you will always be able to beat the boss without exception because of the possibility to grind a level or two. Not once have I felt like a boss was truly overpowered. Rather, that I, myself, was underpowered. And that is something that's easy to fix. 

Now, something I really appreciate about this game is that you have 3 playable characters. One of which is unlocked by finishing the game with one of the other two. This is because the final one is the hardest one to play and to minimize sploilers for the other two. The reason for that is something you will have to find out for yourself. The last one also has the one true story, meaning, the heaviest plot. This gives the game amazing replayability. 

That is about the best I can give you. If this has not cleared things up for you regarding gameplay and such, I'd say you oughta simply look up a video and see for yourself. Try to minimize spoilers, however! So, to conclude my review, this game is heavily recommended by myself among others.

13953385.review:
[h1]很久以后我才能理解，《永远的伊苏》中永远二字究竟代表了什么 [/h1]

不同人喜欢上伊苏有着不同的理由，而让我真正喜欢上伊苏的理由，便是她的名字。《YS1&2 Eternal》正版包装盒上，莉莉娅在逗着璐玩，帅气的亚特鲁靠在一旁看着她，上面大大的五个汉字，永远的伊苏。伊苏是什么？是大魔王的名字吗？还是一位国王？为什么要说它是永远的？长生不老吗？一种莫名的感动与情愫在我的心中生根发芽。

拿到psp，控制着亚特鲁，小心翼翼地踏上梅多海南边的阿鲁塔格大陆。在游玩伊苏7的过程中，我一直在思考，伊苏这个词语，究竟是指什么？那里猜测道，可能是指冒险日记吧，或者是指冒险本身，也许伊苏就是西班牙语（笑）里面冒险的音译。

我玩伊苏的顺序，7F612O。玩1和2的时候已经是高考完的那个暑假，之前早已不知道疯玩过多少游戏。当游戏通关，看见亚特鲁说出菲娜二字的时候，我在想，就这样啊，没了吗？为了赶时间，我是看攻略一天通关的。伊苏指的是一个古国，而不是指冒险，永远的伊苏则是指伊苏在1998年的复刻版本，并不是我想的那样。

永远的伊苏，ys eternal，并没有太多的含义，却被人为赋予了太多内涵，冒险，拼搏，坚持，永不言弃，从小在脑海里为能配的上这个名字的游戏构建了太多幼稚的蓝图，今日付之一炬。它还是它，没有任何变化，而我却渐渐长大。

看过海贼王的都知道，路飞的第一艘船，黄金梅丽号，英文原名going merry，而不是golden merry，但是每家字幕组却不约而同地默认了这个错误，并把这个音译给传承了下去，一个美妙的误会，成就了这艘伟大的帆船。至于为什么ys eternal要翻译成永远的伊苏，而不是永恒的伊苏，或者是伊苏永恒版，可能是译者随性而为，可能是考虑到平仄声，也可能是把对游戏的理解给体现了上去，我们都不必去深究。或许有一天，当亚特鲁的冒险之旅走向了终点，当falcom不再推出伊苏的续作，永远的伊苏这五个字所带给我们的意义，在那一刻，将会超越它所表达的本身...

[h1]steam汉化补丁 [/h1]  http://steamcn.com/t103507-1-1  （可正常解锁成就）

13948040.review:
This game is loads of fun. Combat is smooth and rewarding, not too complicated but it's not just buttonmashing either. The platforming is done very well, challenging but not frustrating. Bosses are awesome (as far as I've gotten). 
Only niggle (ugh, really steam? I'm saying n.i.g.g.l.e) is if you're really having trouble with a boss, it may be you're just underleveled. The game doesn't really emphasize your level so it's easy to miss, but I found that after going back and gaining 4 levels, the boss that was seriously kicking my behind, was suddenly pretty easy (although you'll still need to learn each boss' attackpatterns). Luckily though, grinding those 4 levels was very quick, probably no more than half an hour or so, and didn't feel like traditional grinding (aka boring) at all.
One comment though, everyone's saying how tough the game is... Well, it's not easy, but you might think it's a frustrating experience. As far as I'm concerned it's not. It offers a challenge, but it never feels unfair and to me personally on normal mode I find it's just right (and I'm not normally a glutton for punishment, still havent dared to start up dark soulds ;-))
I haven't gotten anywhere near completing this game yet, but just wanted to share this quick review because the game is still on sale for another 21 hours or so. So what are you waiting for? Go buy it!

13909576.review:
Do you like ARPG, awesome story and don't mind anime style? Well, then this is what you have been searching for your whole life.

General Overview:
As you start the game, you can select between playing Hugo and Yunica. Hugo is like an SMG, you can spam your basic attacks like crazy, but is slower than a slowpoke. And Yunica has oven mittens... oh, and an axe, and is quite mobile. After that you can choose your difficulty, whereas nightmare really is a nightmare, and easy for Hugo players (yes, I hate him and I can't play him).
In this game, nightmare actually adds stuffs like attacks to the enemies, not just way more health and damage. Don't worry if you get stuck on a boss for 3+ hours in this mode.
Upgrading your character is also possible. You get small crystals which are your ingame-coins. In Nightmare every crystal is 1 point worth. In every other difficulty, I think, the bigger crystals give way more points.

The story:
The goddesses are nowwhere to be found on Ys. It's your job to go to the surface and find them. Of course, they are in the giant Darm Tower, the lair of the evil guys. Depending on which character you play, the story changes a bit. You get a few different bosses and other cutscenes. Due to this, you want to play it again, just to see how everything plays out for each character.
Overall, to leave it mostly spoilerfree: Each story had it's emotional part and was well thought-out.

Gameplay:
Hugo: Will make your hands hurt (You should map a key to autopress the shoot button 30x a second)
Yunica: Solid Movement, good attack speed, fun to play and mittens.
There are a lot of enemies. Some are just powered up versions of older enemies, others are completely new. Especially on Nightmare difficulty you have to be very carefully to choose how to deal with the enemy. Some are almost completely immun to your skills. Learing the patterns of your foes helps a great deal.

Setting:
You play in a huge tower. However, this doesn't mean the interior is all the same. Every time after one of the bigger bosses, the tower changes completely. One time you play with lava, the other time you play with sand and also mirrors!

Unlockables:
Yes, this game has unlockables. Once you complete the game with any character, you unlock something awesome and the boss rush mode. After you finish the game with every character, you get the arena mode and a shop. In the first you defeat enemies for points, which then can be exchanged for stuff in the latter one. The shop allows you to buy many things, like powered up spells, Hugo still sucks though.

Soundtrack:
Just listen to the trailer music. It's so awesome! The rest is also pretty good.

Long story short:
Buy it, so we get even more Ys on steam!

13803584.review:
Another JRPG game. Yes, another great game. As a fan of rpg games. I can say that Ys origin have alot of rich stories from different perspective of the characters. This is an rpg with action that requires more than repeatedly hitting the same buttons. If you have played a YS game before then you probably know what I'm talking about.

The buttons are simple, it's easy as 1 2 3. There are 5 modes that you can play. Which are the Very Easy, Easy, Normal, Hard & Nightmare. A single playthrough on Nightmare takes about 30 hours the first time through, it's pretty hard. So those repeatedly buttons will require more than skills to finish it. There are 3 different characters that you can play, different skills, different stories, and different outfits. lol. 

From the artworks and cutscenes, it takes creativity in order to create something like this. I can't say I like it, I love it. There's alot of things you can do here, you won't get bored I assure you.

After completing the game, you get to experience new menu's from the game which includes the arena mode, boss rush and such. If you're really planning to 100% complete this game, goodluck. 

What I didn't liked about the game is that, the dialogues are pretty much the same for the characters but your experience will be pretty much the same each time aside from different attack methods and skills of the characters. You'll understand this if you play the game.

So all in all, if you don't have this game. You're missing out 1 great rpg game. 8/10.

13798852.review:
Sorry for this naive first review of mine. I'll make sure to come back later and polish it up. :)

I've never played any Ys game before, but I'm thoroughly enjoying my playthrough so far. Only about 6 floors in so I have no idea howmuch there is left and I'm repeatedly getting my rear handed to me on nightmare mode first playthrough. I have to say this is one of the few games where constant death doesn't bother me as it generally feels like I made a mistake.

So far the enemies have been scaling really well in all of their drops, and anytime I get stuck on a boss (so far both I've run into one) I don't mind going back and grinding a level or two to beef up my stats and try again and feel a noticeable difference. Leveling feels really solid so far as I feel a discernible, if not momentous, difference each time I gain a level, and makes me feel rewarded for hard work.

The controls feel pretty tight with the combat and platforming working very well to challenge your mastery of the game's mechanics. I can't say I've blamed hitboxes or funky camera angles so far whenever I fail to make a jump or whatnot, and that's a solid plus in my book.

Want a challenging game that could very well dunk you on the first practice fight? (Yea that happened, and it felt great). Do you enjoy platforming? Do you like feeling rewarded every time you grind up a level or want upgrades that make you think about a purchase? This game is probably for you.

13706358.review:
This game is what revived ARPGs for me. Fast paced combat, enough story to keep you mildly invested, and multiple characters to help fit more than one type of playstle. Ys Origin has many [noticible] flaws and successes, most of which make it the game it is today.

Pros: 
3 Playable characters- We have your battle axe wielding berserker-style teenager, your snooty mage, and your "Git gud and unlock me" Character. Each one plays differently because of movement, magic skills, or how well they can manage themselves in, what I like to call, "crisis" situations (instances where you end up in a terrible spot and thinking/reacting fast is your only means of survival".
Jumping- FINALLY, A GAME WHERE I CAN PLAY AN RPG, FIGHT IN REAL TIME, AND JUMP!!!! Moving in 3 dimensions makes platforming puzzles and combat reach another level of challenging.
Puzzles- Puzzles are NEVER stupidly difficult and one particular puzzle can actually be solved without getting a "mandatory" upgrade nearby as 2 of the 3 characters. Puzzles are more meant to keep you from "completely" blitzing through the game.
Story- Story is spaced out enough that it will never wholely interrupt your climb through the tower, but will still be there to keep you interested
Boss Fights- Probably the crowning achievement of Ys games, the boss fights will almost ALWAYS let you have a ton of fun on any difficulty (Yes, even people like me who are frustrated on higher difficulties still enjoy Nightmare mode/Inferno mode for Oath in Felghana). The fact that most of them keep the same pace, or even speed up a bit near the end of the fight, keeps the adrenaline pumping and makes victories that much sweeter.
Difficulty select- You can't change once you start...but at the beginning there are multiple difficulties for the casual/hardcore masochist in all of us. Very Easy mode for the people who just want to beat the game, all the way up to Nightmare for the people who want to be challenged/punished for slightly better unlockable rewards.
Music- FOR THE LOVE OF EVERYTHING SACRED AND DEMONIC IN ALL WORLDS, THIS MUSIC IS AMAZING :L I am a SLAVE to the soundtracks in Ys games! Fanboying aside....we DO have many memorable tracks and a few that may put you to sleep (I'm looking at you 2nd sector >.<) but the tracks are all VERY good standalone....just not always for extended periods of time. The BGM will be the same for the ENTIRE time you are in a sector/until you enter a boss area, so get used to them.


Cons- 
Combat playstyles- Each character can only really play one way...turning trash mob combat into tedium when you are a few levels shy of doing any real damage to enemies. Trash mobs WILL eventually turn into beat-em up sections if you need to go level grinding for any reason.
Level to Damage scaling- You will get new armor and be able to upgrade your weapon as you play through the game but at the same time your level is just as dependant on your damage. If you are even 2 levels shy of where you "should be" you will do little to no damage. You will literally get a small damage/defense spike around certain levels just so you keep up, a pattern present in Ys: Oath in Felghana as well. The same applies to having a weapon too low level. I was at the 3rd boss of the game as the 1st playable character and I noticed I could barely do 2 damage to the guy. Turns out, I missed an upgrade partway through the tower section I was in; because the MOMENT I got it the boss was taking normalized damage again. Upgrade (as a result) are NOT optional, which may kill the game for you if you are playing on Hard/Nightmare and you are going in blind. 
Glitches- The game is relatively glitch-free from my 160-170 hours on record, but occasionally you will witness things like falling through a floor during an attack or clipping into things that stay relatively solid. Nothing too bad, but it did hurt a little getting to the true final boss and falling through the floor RIGHT as I pulled out my nuke move.
Upgrades- Remember how I said upgrades "should" be optional in places? This is where the game has the potential to be a real deal breaker for some. Most RPGs have proven that treasure chests are relatively optional unless something you NEED is in them. Ys: Origin loves planting things that make not getting OHKO'd/combat even remotely possible late game IN treasure chests and then giving you free reign to ignore them. This is not a complaint, but this HAS halted/slowed the progress of a few people Ive helped out on the forums. You should ALWAYS go for chests you see...even if it looks like a pain in the butt to get if you want to have a decent time above Easy mode.


Overall, I give this an 8/10, its EASILY one of my favorite games (especially out of my Steam Library) but even I can see where this game would piss someone off.

If you are already a Falcom fan, then I don't need to encourage you more to go play it. 
Ys Origin brings you the tale of 700 years before the first game. The epic conflict you had in the first game is finally revealed, and what a Hell of a start it is. In terms of story it stands strong, and playing between each character may cause the game to feel repeatable, but it's actually done well. It's easy to get to the 100% clearing, but for 100% upgrades you really need to have a love for grinding. And as always in true Ys fashion, if you think this game isn't hard enough there is the Hellish "Nightmare" mode.

13073807.review:
Probably the quickest I've ever gone from demo to purchase.

As Ys tends to go, it's a ballbuster, but a damn fun one.  Combat is surprisingly flexible for its simplicity.  The set piece boss fights are creative, complex, and completely unforgiving, but for the most part tuned very well -- a player who's practiced up can take them down reliably and feel like a total badass in the process.  Experience gain is tuned to scale based on the level difference between you and your opponent, so you catch up very quickly when underleveled but can always crank out an extra level for an edge against something.

There are exceptions, of course.  Kishgal is capable of randomly screwing you depending on which moves he does in succession, and a couple bosses (Gelaldy, Pictimos) are long and tedious enough to stop feeling fun after the first half of their HP bar.  The latter third of the game is extremely melee-unfriendly, and poor Yunica is largely reduced to spamming one special attack.

12892719.review:
Ys... Легендарное королевство Ис процветало под управление двух богинь и шести жрецов, пока нашествие демонов не заставило оставшихся в живых искать спасения в небесах. Так появилось Святилище Соломона - парящий среди облаков город. Но неожиданно богини пропадают забрав с собой таинственную  Чёрную жемчужину  - источник всей магии, а без нее летающий остров неизбежно рухнет. Жрецы решают собрать спасательный отряд из рыцарей и магов и отправить их на поиски беглянок.
[list]
[*] С самого начала у нас два героя на выбор - молодая неопытная Юника и хладнокровный и серьезный Хьюго. Первая ловко крошит всех врагов топором, а второй является магом и расстреливает всех из посоха и Глаз Факта - семейного артефакта в виде сфер-спутников. После прохождения любой компании нам откроется и третий персонаж (дабы не спойлерить назову его Когтём) - быстрый боец ближнего боя. В целом первые две кампании мало чем отличаются, те же локации и боссы, лишь небольшие различия в сценках и диалогах. А вот третья история показывает подоплеку происходящего и истинную концовку всего сюжета, который в принципе не блещет особыми поворотами. А вот герои хоть и шаблонны, но неплохо прописаны и даже банальные сентенции от них не вызывают отторжения.
[*]Геймплей: мы проносимя по многочисленным этажам Башни Дарма кроша в пыль разнообразных монстров и решая несложные загадки, прерываясь лишь на покупку улучшений и битвы с боссами. Почти все загадки завязаны на простом исследовании уровней или бэктрекинге, а хотелось бы больше разнообразия и секретов (потенциально интереснейшая маска, показыающая скрытые пути и скрывающая живых существ, используется за игру всего пару раз)
Игра по-хорошему сложна - боссы разные, к ним надо находить свой подход и тактику, лобовая атака работает разве что на легкой сложности
[*] Арт отличный, саундтрек тоже на уровне - хотя больше всего мне понравился трек из опенинга.
[/list]
8/10 - если вы поклонник Action RPG, то Ys Origin определенно стоит внимания.

12884205.review:
Ys Origin is an excellent game. I was expecting an average action rpg but it ended up being one of my favorite action rpgs to date. The game can be quite difficult at certain points, especially boss battles, even on the easier difficulties. Also the entire soundtrack is superb. 

So far I've finished the game with Yunica and I've started playing the game as the other two characters (the second of those two must be unlocked by beating the game with either Yunica or Hugo). Each character plays differently from the others and the story for each character is also different (although your going to be running through the same areas and fight most of the same bosses as well). 

After beating the game with a character it unlocks an arena mode for that character, other unlockables are also unlocked after beating the game with all three of the characters. 

I'd recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of action games or action rpgs, I'd say its a must buy.

12341988.review:
I absolutely love this game. As many have already have said, there are two characters to play as initially, with a third being unlocked after you beat the game with either of the first two. I recommend playing the game at least three times, once with each character. The order I played in was: Yunica (close/medium-range), Hugo (medium/long-range), then the secret character (very close-range). All three have interwining stories, and you only get the full picture after beating the game with all three. 

The story itself is interesting, and makes you want to keep playing long after the credits roll. The good thing about Ys Origin is that you don't need any backstory from the previous games, due to this title being a prequel to the rest of the series. The combat is addictive, with the environments and enemies changing often enough so as not to get repetitive. The soundtrack is sublime, and will make you want to listen to it even outside of the game.

I played the game on Normal difficulty, and doing so will probably net you 8-10 hours of game for each character. However, I recommend playing on Hard, because grinding even a little bit on Normal will make the game obscenely easy. Overall, if you like action-RPGs, a great soundtrack, and a great story, you can't go wrong with this one.
