12322934.review:
Adding RPG stats to an action game always weakens the game, but despite that flaw Ys Origin has some of the best hack and slash boss battles on Steam outside of Ys Oath in Felghana and the bosses alone make the game worth playing. Each is a brutal brick wall requiring a lot of learning and retries to get all the patterns down, and, yes, unfortunately, a touch of grinding is required sometimes. There are levels you are meant to be at, as the boss time attack mode makes clear, and sometimes you don't get to those levels without going back and bashing mooks for a while. Still, at the right level, you can treat Ys like a real game and not yet another RPG grindfest.

Other problems, it's flatly worse than Ys Oath in Felghana. The mook combat is more interesting but the addition of multiple characters with different styles screws the balancing all up.

The story tells an "origin" that doesn't really ever justify itself. The priests of Ys had no grand mystery behind them and other than locking you in a dreary endless tower and throwing a lot of redone Ys 1 and 2 enemies at you, this story ends up offering no real insight to the Ys story, nor does it ever really get interesting enough to justify the freakishly long unskippable cutscenes.  Oath had a bloated tale too but at least it was a rollicking good adventure. Origin isn't even that.

Still, if you liked Oath and want another helping of those amazing boss battles, Origin is worth your time. Even if the balancing is off, the variety is here in spades. If you haven't played Oath yet, go get that.

12192573.review:
Most people, if you ask them to name a 25-year-old game series in which you explore dungeons and fight monsters, will likely say “The Legend of Zelda”. Even though the Ys series is as old as Zelda and has enjoyed immense popularity in Japan since the first game, Ys 1: Ancient Ys Vanished (1987), the series has never been that popular outside the Orient.

A few entries did make it west on PS2 and PSP, either through Konami in 2005 with Ys VI: Ark of Napishtim (the first English release of the series in thirteen years) or XSEED’s masterful handling of translations starting with Ys: The Oath in Felghana. XSEED released Ys: The Oath in Felghana, a remake of Ys III: Wanderers from Ys (1989), on Steam in March. This is the first time most PC gamers get to experience what is (in terms of number of game releases) the largest Eastern RPG series second only to Final Fantasy. 

Released on Steam in May, Ys Origin is the seventh game in the Ys series and a prequel. It takes place first in terms of chronology, 700 years before the events of “Ancient Ys Vanished” (Ys I & II). As you explore a huge vertical dungeon known as “Darm Tower”, the game elaborates on much of the series’ backstory, including characters, mystical artifacts and locations. 

There are three playable characters (one is initially locked until you beat the game once with either of the other two), each has their own story and combat style. Yunica, a young knight, uses an axe and sword for close-range melee. Hugo Fact, genius magician and all-round asshole, shoots bullets and is the easier of the two to play. We’re not going to spoil the third character for you.

Combat is fast and action-packed, with enemies having clear and recognizable patterns to their attacks. As you hack-and-slash your way up the tower, there are some mild puzzles to solve and mild platforming elements to jump through. There’s a kind of momentum system to keep you pushing forward: as you kill enemies without stopping, you gain a bonus to the rate at which you get experience points and “SP”. The “SP” points are spent to permanently buff your character, such as increasing resistance to negative effects like poison or confuse , or to upgrade your armour.

The boss fights are where the game (and series) really strut its stuff. While mowing through general enemies is pretty easy, boss fights require focus. You’ll need to learn their attack patterns, figure out which skills to use against them, and if you’re really into that kind of thing there are Time Attack and Boss Rush challenge modes.

11875456.review:
So, what is it you want from a game? Pretty visuals? An excellent story? Intense action? A challenge? If the answer to the last two questions are "yes", you should try this game. The anime/JRPG style visuals may not be everyone's cup of tea, so take that into account. The story is by no means bad, but nothing that'll keep you at the edge of your seat. But there are some really good reasons why to play this game. 

First of all, the gameplay. Fast-paced and fluid hack&slash action typical for an ARPG with the difference that it has a vertical dimension as well, adding some platforming to the whole concept. Initially you get to pick between two characters, and can unlock a third one. The story remains more or less the same (it's best described as 3 different points of view), but there are significant differences in how the characters are played, each of the 3 offers a unique gameplay experience. You can pick either a controller or the KB/mouse duo, both work just fine. The configuration tool is user-friendly and offers a lot of freedom in defining your desired configuration.

There are five difficulty levels, ranging from "very easy" to "nightmare". The game is quite challenging, don't be shy to try it on a lower difficulty if you just don't seem to move forward. The strongest point of this game are the numerous and intense boss-battles, which test your reflexes and wits alike. You won't get anywhere with the "hit it until it stops moving" idea even on "very easy". Expect to hit the retry button numerous times, sometimes it's not obvious what you need to do from the start. Explore and experiment, it's fun! 

Finished story mode with all 3 characters? The game still has replay value! In the Time Attack mode, you can test your mettle against the game's bosses without having to replay the whole game again. And it doesn't end there. While Time attack can be played right after completing the game with one character, once you clear the story mode with all 3, you gain access to Arena Mode, where you fight waves of enemies from the level of your choice and collect SP (the game's currency) to unlock bonus content. 

The soundtrack is simply amazing. Masterpiece after masterpiece, greatly adding to the enjoyment the game has to offer.

If "challenge" is your middle name, then you shouldn't miss this game.

The verdict: 8.9/10

11816489.review:
Ys origin is a great game,its an action-jrpg that has all the elements that makes Ys series great, the huge difficult bosses, the fast paced action, the amazing music. 
This one follows the style of the modern 3D Ys games like oath in felghana and ark of napishtim but the story is a prequel of the whole Ys series, before Ys I & II chronicles. It does a great job explaining how the story started with interesting characters and a plot that suits the game. Dont expect an amazing plot but its decent.
As for the content, the game offers three playable characters (one fo them is unlocked after you complete the game with one of the first two) with different story for each one, also there is boss rush,time attack and an arena mode, so there is lots of things to do. Just for completion with one character you will need about 12 hours in normal difficulty.
The game can be really hard so think carefully before starting it in hard mode for a first playthrough.

I highly recommend this game for hack and slash action-jrpg fans.

11798981.review:
Okay, let's just get the obvious out of the way right now: The intro to this game is LONG. LOOOOONG. Like, possibly the longest intro to an RPG I've ever played.

HOWEVER, once you get past the intro, you're introduced to the meat of the gameplay, and holy hell is it satisfying! The combat in Ys: Origin is fast placed hack n slash that seems mindless at first, but if you just mindlessly spam attacks with no thought, you will die. A lot.

In fact, even if you're careful, you will most likely die a lot, because this game is HARD. The normal enemies are usually no trouble, though there are indeed cases where they can chump you if you're not careful, but the real meat of the difficulty lies in the boss battles.

If you're at all familiar with the Ys series, than you probably know that one of the series' most lauded aspects is the incredibly designed, incredibly difficult boss fights, and Origin is no exception. You will most likely die to a boss at least once before you learn how to deal with them. And each boss as their own styles, attacks, and strategies, so each boss feels fresh and exciting.

Also, did I mention the music? Because HOLY HELL the music is amazing. Quite possibly one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.

All in all, if you're looking for an RPG with fast paced action, an interesting story, amazing bosses, amazing soundtrack, and a difficulty level that constantly keeps you on your toes, then Ys Origin is for you. In fact, give the whole Ys series a try. Its a great series, and Falcom and XSeed are great companies that deserve your support.

11798339.review:
The Ys series is old, having started back in 1987. One of the first action-oriented JRPGs, and one of the few series that still sticks around today. There's a reason for that, it's a series that has evolved over time without losing it's roots. It's still all about running around, killing monsters, growing stronger, finding key items and fighting challenging bosses.
In that, it's pretty much a cousin to the Legend of Zelda. 

It does have it's own style of combat, and it's own setting (generic by today's standards, but when the series was new it was one that helped build the stereotypes) and each entry tends to have it's own twists and tricks. 

This is one of the later entries to the series, and uses 3d environments with good-looking 2d spritework for the characters. It mostly sticks to overhead view, but there's sections that twist the viewpoint along the way.
story-wise it's the prequel to the story. As such, the mainstay hero swordsman Adol is nowhere in sight yet, and instead you have 2 playable characters with their unique playstyle (with a 3rd one to unlock).
Each character has a different playstyle, and gets different special skills to use.

Pros:
- Game provides a good challenge on Normal difficulty, ramping up quickly but smoothly. Easier & harder difficulties are also available.
- Bosses are memorable, with fairly tricky attack patterns at times (and mostly references to the bosses from earlier games in the series)
- The playable characters do handle completely different, adding replayability
- Crisp high-res artwork, holding up well today even though the original Japanese version of the game dates back to 2006
- Pretty cool soundtrack
- One of the playable characters is a non-sexualized, non-stereotypical female protagonist. That seems to be a big deal in this day and age so I'll list it as a pro.
- Plenty of customization options. (if using a gamepad, you will want to remap the pause/menu button though - for some sillt reason it's not mapped to start button by default)
- Solid controls
- Update: Unlockable bonus modes, with leaderboards and all, which start unlocking once you complete the game

Cons:
- While good-looking, there isn't that much variety in the different environments you'll run through
- There's a couple of weird things, like a key equipable item not being in the equipment screen, but tucked away in between the usable items instead.
- No auto-saving. This being an old-school game it uses a savepoint mechanism, which works well. What's weird is that savepoints do work as checkpoints when you die, but don't auto-save to an actual save game.
- Non-skippable cutscenes. Which is annoying if you want to start a new game but can't skip the minutes-long opening movie to get into the action. Update: At least the long animated scenes become skippable after you complete the game once. So it's mostly annoying if (like me) you want to try both initial characters without beating the game first.

11781576.review:
Ys Origin is an original JRPG/Hack & Slash game with really good fighting mechanics, a decend story and Metroidvania style levels.If that's not enough praise, let me say it's one of the best games I've ever played.

You first (first because you can unlock more characters) play as Yunica Tovah, a young woman who has sworn to protect the godesses of her world; a girl who is looked down upon by all the other guards because she possesses no magical powers whatsoever. A girl, that proves to be more than valuable and capable without magical powers in rescuing the godesses and the whole world in the course of the story.

The gameplay feels really slick, it's not simply a matter of button mashing but you have to react to what enemies do and figure out strategies to effectively kill each one of them. They have certain movesets that are predictable and thus can be learned - something I really appreciate. There is no buIlsh!t going on with the enemies. If you fail, it's your fault - it's quite Dark Souls'esque in this regard. Especially noteworthy are the bosses that are all very unique in their mechanics and that are thoroughly fun to fight. Each and every one of them has move-sets that are to be learned and understood if you want to defeat them. It's not too difficult to figure out what to do because each of their movements can be predicted by the animations they have - to me it seems that's one of the biggest strengths that Japanese/Asian games have over western games (the rules to beat the game are very clear - it's still tough).

The level design is great. There may be some backtracking involved but it's really only if you didn't check everything properly in your first run-through. Everything is connected in a consistent and logical manner and there are various styles of areas.

The sound design is great as well. The feedback you get for your actions is quickly ingrained into your brain, and helps you understand what's happening even if you can't take in all the visual information at the time - perfect. The soundtrack is pumping and very well done, suits the overall game.

The graphics are not top notch but they suit the kind of game Ys Origins is. They are probably even perfect for what the game tries to achieve. They are simplistic but nice to look at, everything fits together and there is nothing that sticks out as ugly or unfitting. Especially noteworthy are the character models that look very nice.

My one problem with the game is that if you are underleveled, you will have a really tough time against some of the bosses. An unnecessarily tough time that may force you to go back and grind 2-3 levels. Which doesn't take too much time but is tedious nonetheless and could've been circumvented by making levels count less and making items count more for the overall strength of your character.

All in all - who woulda thunk it after reading what I just wrote - Ys is one of my favorite games of all times.

I won't give you a stupid random number for this game though - judgements of games are always subjective.

If anything, I'd give the same rating Conan O'Brien gave for Tomb Raider:

Edit: Sorry, but it doesn't start you at the right time, even though I linked with time. Jump to 7 min, 30s for the rating :)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xCe8-1dbXZc&t=7m30s

11768614.review:
Ys Origins is a mix between Diablo and Zelda, and it is very fun to play. Unfortunately the great gameplay, soundtrack and visuals are dragged down by downright cringeworthy dialogue and a by the numbers story with a very flat ending. The graphics are also a bit dated even for 2006 when this originally came out. However the game still has a charm of its own. The character sprites are well made and environments have clear and different themes and feels. The fast pace of the monster slaying is maybe a bit too often grinded into a halt when you have to sit through lengthy and uninteresting line exchanges between the monotone and cliche characters.

One interesting thing of note is the other main character of the game, Hugo. He should probably get an award for the most edgy video game protagonist ever. Most of the cringe material of the game comes from his teenage rebel attitude. The story might have been much less cringy had I picked Yunica for playable character, but I also think the edginess is kinda charming and memorable.

In conclusion the rock solid gameplay and soundtrack totally redeem this game from any negatives I might have towards it. It was a blast to play and a definite recommendation.

11760987.review:
TL;DR: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=077kiivrrCs (no ver completo, para evitar spoilers de las peleas)

Otra obra maestra de Falcom, Ys Origin mantiene la formula de dificultad y excelente soundtrack que ha hecho del resto de la saga un favorito en quienes (como yo, por ejemplo) han jugado los juegos anteriores.

Ys Origin es un ARPG donde el jugador ha de hacerse paso a traves de hordas de monstruos, resolver puzzles y no morir (esto ultimo es importante) para eventualmente enfrentarse a poderosos "jefes", cada uno con su tematica de lucha y formas de poner a prueba la habilidad de quien los enfrenta, y digo habilidad, ya que si bien el juego puede ser dificil, a la vez es justo; si uno muere, es por culpa de uno y no por problemas de camara o sucesos aleatorios... sino porque uno ha de seguir mejorando.

Afortunadamante el juego cuenta con multiples dificultades, que van desde facil a nightmare para adecuarse a cada jugador y multiples historias (una para cada personaje) que extienden bastante el tiempo de juego que podemos obtener de este ARPG, eso sin contar la posibilidad de desbloquear otros modos, como luchas contra los jefes con tiempo por si uno esta de animos de repetir las peleas sin jugar desde el principio.

Omitire detalles de la historia, por razones obvias dentro del presente review.

Finalmente, si bien mi falta de elocuencia puede no hacer parecer "gran cosa" a Ys Origin (y en realidad, a toda la saga Ys), de todas formas recomiendo revisar algun video de juego en Youtube (pero no mucho, que parte del desafio es aprender por uno mismo como enfrentarlos), como el que puse en el TL;DR; y que vean por uds. si el estilo de juego es de su agrado, que por mi parte espero ansioso la traducción de mas juegos de Falcom y considero una perdida que tan pocos conozcan este espectacular juego.

Gracias por leer este review!.

11747817.review:
Ys isn't as bad as the first few hours make it seem.  There's enough about it that's bad enough to give it a thumbs down, but it's definitely done some things pretty well.  This review lists major points concisely with more detailed explanations at the bottom.

Here are the flaws I've seen so far:
-Character and item upgrade systems are pathetically bad.
-Uninspired levels.
-The 'puzzles' involve finding an item and backtracking to use it.  
-Framerate issues with some graphical effects.
-Controls need autofire and autocharge.  Other control problems may be specific to me.
-Too many rpg text dialogs that can't be skipped.  
-The difficulty curve isn't right.  
-The rate of levelling needs adjusting, and the effect of gaining levels is not done well.  It increases damage done and decreases damage taken, altering boss fight difficulty too much.

Game's strong points:
+The bosses are very challenging with fully-avoidable attacks
+The action is fast-paced.  
+The graphics are colorful, and I like the graphical style of the characters.

Regarding difficulty,
On Hard difficulty with the magic user, the monsters are a joke, unable to threaten the player.  The bosses are very challenging.  On nightmare difficulty with the melee character, the (skippable) trash monsters are about right, but the bosses are extremely challenging.  
There is at least 1 boss fight that cannot be won without grinding due to its being a dps race.  It is not obvious that grinding is the intended (and only) way to win the encounter.  Grinding 5 levels for that fight also reduced the boss's attacks from 40 dmg/hit to 9 dmg/hit.  I do not know how hard those bosses are supposed to hit, and I suspect the developers don't either.  
Without grinding, nightmare bosses can take 1-10 hours to beat, including the time to learn their moves.

Unskippable dialogs
are ubiquitous and boring.  Even if I were interested in reading the story of a hero who rescues princesses and saves the world, my replays through the game would not be.
The intro cinematic is well done, but it can't be skipped either.  It takes at least 15 minutes to start a new game due to the unskippable cut scenes and dialog.

The controls
desperately need an autofire button and a way to hold down the magic charge button.  Using outside configuration utilities creates some problems in the game such as menus opening and closing due to autofire.  Holding down the magic charge button while imtermittently holding down the attack button and periodically jumping has led to some hand soreness.  Without autofire, the repetitive button presses will cause a lot of repetitive stress.
Even after some configuration, there are still occaisional phantom axis motions, and recharging magic immediately after casting makes it cast twice.

11688404.review:
I got this game on Humble Bundle for $6. I was skeptical whether or not it was worth the asking price of $20.  
After playing through the game with the first character, I can say $20 is a fair price for what it gives. 

The game isn't an "RPG" in the traditional sense that people are used to (i.e. Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest). There isn't much grinding (unless you want achievements) in this and it isn't slow turn based combat where you repeat a set of tactics. Combat is quick, fluid, and fun. Bosses are hard if your difficulty is on hard or above. I died quite a few times to each boss on hard.

Cutscenes aren't so long as to detract from the experience as some people have mentioned in negative reviews.

Cons: Now my primary complaint is that the initial control system is attacking with the keyboard and moving with the mouse. I would recommend inverting this to attacking with the mouse and using the keyboard to move. I.e. the traditional layout for PC games. I cannot understand why this wasn't the default, but it was a simple change in the configuration.

Además el argumento me ha gustado más que el otro Ys mencionado anteriormente aunque el desarrollo es más lineal y con menos backtracking. El juego además tiene triple aliciente ya que tienes 2 personajes al inicio y al pasártelo por primera vez (final falso) se desbloquea el personaje Toal, que es una diosada y además su final es el bueno, mucho mejor que el de su hermano Hugo. 11679827.review:
This game serves as my introduction to the world of Y's (pronounced EES). I've been wanting to play a game in this series for a while and I'm so happy I picked this one up. A Diablo-style action RPG, this game is hella fun. I'm several hours into my first playthrough and have really enjoyed it so far. Challenging boss fights, decent level design that rewards you for exploring while providing a decent story. It's all a very solid and polished experience that's worth your time. A lot of games like this have mecahnics that suffer or that are a bit loose. To me, this is a crucial part of enjoying a game's platforming sections. It's very frustrating when you feel like you told your character to jump from the platform they're on to the one on the right only to find that you were pressing every so slightly in an upwards/downwards direction which caused you to miss the platform and fall into the pit. Not so here. I felt like I had good control over the character and rarely if ever made such a mistake that felt all too common even in AAA titles that are top ranked in their class. 

Overall I really can't find much to fault in this game. To nitpick I'd say the costumes are a bit plain when you're talking to others but this is also refreshing at the same time. It's simple, and practical. I would also say there maybe could have been more variety with the monsters but this doesn't really bother me at all either. It's just a fun game that's knows what it is and has fun being just that. If you like games like this I highly recommend giving it a try.

11476093.review:
Score: 8.5 / 10

I haven't 100%'d the game yet, but I feel like I'm ready to review it after 120 hours of gameplay and 3 playthroughs on nightmare on all characters.

I have played three games from the Ys series so far (Ys I & II, Origin and Felghana) and each one of them clearly shows the extreme effort Falcom and XSEED put into every aspect of the game: super smooth gameplay with solid mechanics and very few bugs or inconsistencies, pretty challenging difficulty, excellent performance, very flexible settings that support even 120hz and up monitors and modern resolutions, the portings are very compatible with modern OSes even though these games are from 2006 and earlier, the anime graphics and the artwork are sweet and pleasant (but not necessarily ultra detailed) and the soundtracks are masterpieces.
In poor words, Falcom consistently does a great job in every aspect of the game and puts a great effort into making every detail perfect and solid. Both the engines of Ys I & II and Origin & Felghana have the perfect balance between graphics, performance and gameplay quality.

I won't talk too much about the plot because I usually don't care about that stuff.
Ys Origin is a prequel set 700 years before the events of Ys I & II and tells about the past of Ys, the twin goddesses, the black pearl and Solomon Shrine. Most of humanity fled to Solomon Shrine (which is on a floating island up in the sky), as the surface got taken over by demons. For the very first time we're not playing as Adol. We will be playing as one member of a group of adventurers (you can choose between 3 characters) sent to investigate on the disappearance of the twin goddesses, who seem to be inside the Darm tower.

Pro / Cons:
+ = pro
- = con

- no more "bump mechanics" from Ys I & II. In my opinion, this combat system was unique and kinda set Ys apart from other action RPG's, also it made boss fights a bit more challenging. Ys Origin & other newer Ys games ditched that system for more generic hack n slash mechanics + magic which is okay but nothing special.
- the game takes place entirely inside of the Darm Tower, so there is not that much variety environment-wise.
- while Ys I had very short but extremely fast & challenging boss fights (except for a few bosses with bugged AI's), the boss fights on Ys Origin are slow and long, and since the bosses heavily rely on RNG, defeating a boss on Nightmare difficulty is 50% skill 50% luck unless you overlevel to fight that luck factor. Either way, there is too much luck involved in boss fights, and sometimes it can become frustrating even if you can actually beat the boss 100% of the times. This also makes boss rush / time attack extremely tedious and frustrating especially on Nightmare where you will be barely equipped to beat the boss. In Ys I & II, on the other hand, the boss fights were 100% skill based and used nearly no RNG-based attacks, but they were so challenging that you had to practice for a bit to master them even if you memorized them, so the results of the boss fights scaled directly with the player's skill.
- there is a lot more grinding required, too much for my tastes. Leveling up for bosses takes much longer and filling the monster book is now random instead of having to kill each mob 31 times.
- the dialogue can be sped up but not skipped. this can be frustrating when playing through the game multiple times.
- the save system does not allow you anymore to save anywhere - you can teleport to save points, but you will have to save there so that adds some useless backtracking when saving before dangerous situations. On the other hand, the teleport system is handy to quickly teleport to every area of the game, but a system like the wings in Ys II would've been enough.
- Alt + F4'ing the game has a chance to corrupt your monster book
+ a playthrough takes about 10 hours if you kill all of the bosses first try and 20-30+ hours if you take a few tries to beat each boss, which is pretty optimal for multiple playthroughs or speedruns.
+ amazing soundtrack with lots of remasters of the original darm tower musics in Ys I
+ lots of references to Ys I & II: remastered bosses, lots of monsters in common, lots of remastered music, some key items in common and the plot is nicely linked and properly explains all of the backstory behind Ys I.
+ very high replay value: each character sees the story from an entirely different perspective, will encounter slightly different bosses and each character's boss fight is balanced differently. There's also an arena mode where you will be able to fight monsters from different areas of the game to gain SP you can use to unlock alternative versions of the characters and other bonus content, including a secret boss. Completing all of the achievements will take up to 6 playthroughs or more. There's also the usual monster book you have to fill by grinding all of the monsters in the game (some are missable), an upgrade system for your characters where you can spend SP earned from mobs, and various Roo's hidden around the game that will give you missable upgrades if you feed them Roda Fruits (also hidden & missable).
+ the achievements where you have to beat two "unbeatable" boss that you normally have to lose to are pretty interesting challenges even though they're heavily rng based
+ retrying bosses doesn't make you go through the dialogue all over again
+ perfect support for the 360 joypad and ps3 joypad + ds3 tool
+ the engine has a minimum guaranteed performance: for example, if there's too many effects on screen some of them will not display, that way there is always a guaranteed minimum framerate even in the worst scenario.
+ the bosses partially retain the "bullet hell on foot" feel that Ys I & II had.

It's not a masterpiece like Ys I & II, but it's an excellent game like most Falcom games and it's certainly worth the price. Highly recommended.

11475162.review:
Some games I buy for the story.
Some games I buy for the gameplay,
Other games I guy for the music.

In the case Ys Origin I bought it for the gameplay and music
However, that is not to say that the story of this game is it weakness.
It have several  stories to tell, although very similar are different enough to deserve a play through of every one of them.
The music, as I said before, is an great reason to buy it since it is so well tuned to the game
and gives you an certain nostalgia.
The weakness of the game however is what all rpg can suffer from, 
the difficulty can be a matter of levels, not skill. 
This can result to you having to do some exp grinding
However, thankfully Ys Origin gives you something for that trouble in the way of unlocking lore as you kill monsters.
That said, the actual fights can be fun and gives you the ability to chose how you want to play the character

And finally you may as yourselves “Which game should I play first? Ys 1 or Ys Origin?”
Since both the first game an Origin has spoiler for each others it can be a hard choice.
However, I recommend playing Origin first since I enjoyed interacting with a certain character in Ys 1 more than I would otherwise had if I hadn't played Origin first.

And  if you are only able to pick one of Ys games for now, make it Origin as it will probably give you a better lasting experience than the other games.

11439320.review:
A++

Le style de jeu est assez basique : sauter dans tous les sens pour esquiver des attaques, tuer des mobs pour récupérer de l'xp et de l'or (SP), sauvegarder régulièrement. Récupérer de nouvelles compétences, améliorer l'équipement, un boss de temps à autres. Rien de bien original, mais le tout très bien fait.
Les trois personnages (Yunica, Hugo et Toal) procurent une expérience de jeu différente à chaque fois. Mais surtout, les dialogues, objets, et salles sont personnalisées. Pour comprendre l'intégralité de l'histoire (assez complexe), il faut faire le jeu entier avec chacun. Et c'est agréable.

Par ailleurs, les cinématiques sont très travaillées, la musique assez bonne et changeante. Les niveaux de difficulté (de very easy à Nightmare) permettent à tout un chacun de finir le jeu.
Le jeu est aussi peu gourmand en ressources, et particulièrement stable.

Bref, un très bon jeu, qui n'a pas besoin de Ys I et II pour être compris (même si ces deux épisodes plus anciens valent le détour)

Une surprise : Même si le jeu est en anglais... allez écouter YSO_019.ogg dans le dossier des musiques du jeu.
Je cherche encore une explication.

Animecilerin Diablo su. Anlayacağınız gibi oyunun türü RPG/Hack and Slash. Yalnız RPG kısmı diablo dan daha fazla. Oyun diablo ya göre daha fazla hikaye odaklı. Bu yüzden çok daha fazla konuşma var. Oyunda biri sonradan açılan toplamda 3 karakter var. İkisini baştan seçebiliyorsunuz ama 3. karakter oyunu bir kez bitirdikten sonra açılıyor ve esas karakter o. O karakterle mutlaka bitirmenizi öneririm. Hem esas hikayeyi görmüş olursunuz hem de oynanış olarak en hızlı ve en zevklisi sonradan açılan 3. karakterdir. Oyun bittikten sonra isterseniz boss rush, time attack gibi challenge modları var onları da oynayabilirsiniz. Level atlama olayı otomatik yani her level atladığınızda Hp niz 6-7 artıyor. Yetenekleri, zırhları, silahları oyun içerisindeki sandıklardan elde ediyorsunuz. Bu yüzden her tarafa bakmaya özen gösterin. Bir yere gidemiyorsanız yüzde 99 orası için uygun itemi bulmamışsınız demektir. Oyun hatta seri bu konuda son derece cimri, direkt size itemi vermiyor, diyalogla ipucu veriyor arayıp bulmasını size bırakıyor.Oynanış olarak gayet rahat ve akıcı. Gamepadiniz varsa çok daha rahat bi oynanışı var. 

Bossları ayrı bir paragraf açayım. Gerçekten çok uğraştırıyorlar. Yapmanız gereken şey 10 levelde kesemediğiniz bosa 13 14 level gitmek. Kasılacaksınız yani. Jrpg oynamak istiyor ama sıratabnlı diye uzak duruyorsanız, ya da diablo benzeri oyunları seviyorsanız Ys tam aradığınız oyun. Origini oynayıp bırakmayın, 1-2 chronicles, felghana, celceta, seven kısacası tüm Yslere bir göz atın. Güzel seridir.

11200476.review:
I tend to be weary of japanese game ports. The PC gaming market is small over there, and it's common for developers to misunderstand PC expectations. Moreover, these types of games attract a passionate fanbase, who will often overlook technical flaws in their reviews.

Good news: none of this applies to Ys Origin. 

The game runs at 60 frames per second without a hitch. Widescreen resolutions are properly supported. There is minimal letterboxing on menus, but devs have added additional graphics on the sides (rather than black bars), a nice touch. 7 hours in, I haven't been able to spot a single bug or glitch. Keyboard controls are implemented and the various tutorial screens actually reference these keys rather than gamepad prompts.

As for the gameplay itself, other reviews give a good overview so there's hardly any need to expand on this. Personal recommandation, don't let your ego get in the way of a fun experience. As someone who finds the Dark Souls series' reputation for punishing difficulty to be largely overblown (and I love all Dark Souls games), Ys Origin's demo boss still handed my ass to me several times on Normal difficulty. Picking Easy for my real playthrough after buying the game, so far it has been appropriately challenging. 

Also worth noting leveling seems to be important in this game. Sometimes, getting two extra levels can be the difference between hitting a boss for 1 damage per hit or 10 damage per hit (those numbers might seem paltry either way, but when you think about it, the latter hits ten times harder). On Easy there hasn't been any need to grind experience so far.

Overall, an excellent game. -75% discounts come and go on a regular basis, and at that price it's a steal if you're even remotely interested in the genre. Heck, I don't even like anime, but one can only stay grumpy for so long in the face of sheer fun.

Un jeu au gameplay dynamique, nerveux et qui propose du challenge le tout enveloppé dans un univers beau et au design soigné, rythmé par des ost sublime, ce jeu est une vrai perle sous tout les angles.

Ce jeu fais parti d'une grande saga qui a débuté dans les année 1980 sur PC-88 (si je ne dit pas
de bêtises c'est une saga contemporaine à Touhou project et Corpse party) et qui n'est pas très
connu chez nous en europe , ce qui est vraiment dommage vu le potentielle.
La Saga des Ys et des Eiyuu densetsu (Legend of Heroes chez nous) gagnerais à être plus
connu.

Le petit plus qui fais toujours plaisir, c'est que ce jeu ne demande pas d'avoir une machine de guerre pour fonctionner et un jeu accessible à la majoritée c'est toujours un plaisir.

Edit:
Au mois de Janvier , le patch français de la communauté est sortie (voir guide de la communautée) le jeu est maintenant jouable entierement en français et les non anglophone pourront s'y interresser.
J'ajoute aussi qu'au mois de Février la version Ps4 d'Ys Origin est sortie entierement traduite en français et cela officiellement.
Profitez de ce jeu il vaut réellement le coup !

11160449.review:
I made a Let's Play from it. I think this is worth it.

There are a lot of games in the Ys series, several of which are on Steam. This is actually a prequel, set hundreds of years before the main series games.

Yet... this is my favorite.

The Ys series are action RPGs. What makes them unique is that a level-up should not be underestimated - it makes the difference between getting served by a boss and dominating it. So grinding feels genuinely rewarding, and something you shouldn't have to do much of if you're not playing on higher levels. Plus, the soundtrack absolutely rocks.

There is a bit of a Metroid feel as you'll be backtracking and searching around for powerups to help you get further into the tower. There are three characters, and for me the game was never really boring enough not to replay with the other characters. Getting all achievements, however, requires beating the game a total of six times, and on the highest difficulty for three of them. Don't think I'm going for that.

The Ys series was never huge on story - you won't find anything revolutionary here. But it's not a problem, since the gameplay more than makes up for it.

In summary: Genuinely fun action, great music, and a great intro into the Ys series. GET THIS GAME.

falcom旗下两大神作系列之一的伊苏。伊苏起源，是我感觉从YS1&2之后伊苏最高峰的杰作之一。
舞台再次回到了一切开始的伊苏古国，再加上人气高涨的双子女神，注定成为一个极具关注度的游戏。

游戏引擎还是falcom所谓看家万年不变的2D引擎，（闪轨之后终于换3D了），虽然是2D引擎，但是在建模细节上很好的体现了日本人的精细作风风格。可以做细微模糊的动作中感受人物的心理，情感，当然这其中也有出色的falcom立绘功底。其实说道这里，很多都不需要过多的介绍了，在天朝比我熟悉falcom的人一样是非常多的。falcom的伊苏和英雄传说系列足足影响了整个日式RPG爱好者的几代人。

爽快的战斗方式，有趣的迷宫设定，感人肺腑的剧情演出，配合上不同的场景和不同的音乐搭配演绎，时燃时泪。完全的日式风格~没有任何理由拒绝这个游戏。

推荐如果还没玩过这个的，喜欢日式RPG的话，一定推荐玩！

后话：可惜伊苏起源之后，该系列又再次陷入了低潮中，而falcom的重心，也逐渐转移到专注一个更具有广泛影响和人气的的英雄传说-轨迹系列中了。作为ARPG的伊苏，何时才能更加绽放光辉呢.....还有就是，有生之年，希望看到轨迹结局！！

后话2：庆祝中文闪轨上市~ 期待9月即将发售的闪轨2！falcom一生推！

11157675.review:
A prequel to the long-running Ys series, Ys Origins tells the story of Darm Tower before the events of Ys I & II. Unlike most Ys games, you don't play as familiar, red-haired protagonist Adol Christin, but rather one of two characters (there is also a 'secret' third character), the axe-wielding Yunica and the mage Hugo. This is a different take on the series than most entries, and is a welcome change as there is a lot of variety with the playstyles of each character, and this also adds to the replay value as you can play through the game multiple times with different characters, the story being slightly different for each as well. 

The story is rather bare-bones, but mildly interesting, particularly if you are an Ys fan or a fan of traditional fantasy storylines. Nothing to set the world on fire, but the main characters are likable (particularly Yunica) and the story does not get in the way of the game's main strength: the fast-paced, action-RPG combat. If you've never played an Ys game, particularly the older titles, the game plays as a mix of a top-down hack n' slash and a 2.5 platformer. Many of the skills you gain have dual uses for both platforming and combat, and there is a decent variety of abilities. That being said, there is much more combat than platforming in the game, and while the platforming can be occasionally frustrating, the combat is where the series, and this game in particular, truly shines. Combat requires you to quickly chain together attacks, make smart use of your skills, and avoid enemy attacks by dodging and jumping. Basic enemies are not too difficult, though there is a wide variety of enemy types to fight, all with their different skillsets and strategies. The bosses are the main attraction, being both difficult and surprisingly epic for a game without state-of-the-art graphics. 

One more thing about this game, and the Ys series as a whole: the music is FANTASTIC! Some of the best videogame music I have ever heard is from this series, and this entry keeps the bar set high. There are quite a few stellar tracks, many of which are boss themes. Overall, I would reccomend this game to any fan of the series, any fan of action RPG's, and any fan of Japanese games. If none of these categories apply to you, then pick this gem up on sale. Trust me, you will not be dissapointed, and maybe you'll become another fan of this underappreciated (but spectacular) series.

I am really amused how much good reviews this game got on steam. Most likely game is overrated because of nostalgia.

pros:
- Great platformer
- Story
- Soundtrack (for those who like such music)

cons: 
- not an RPG at all (by modern standarts)
- unskippable video: long and predictable hence boring
- uninspired level design, too repetitive
- Spam attack button to win on hard difficulty.
- Spam attack button to win on nightmare difficulty.
*** for those who are going to argue about difficulty, yes, bosses may be tough, everything else - just spam attack button.

gameply:
1. Watch unskippable anime (or just minimize the game and do something fun)
2. Spam action button to skip tons of text (or read it if you haven't played any RPG video games in your life)
3. move your character for a few seconds
4. spam action button to skip text (or read it)
5. spam action button to defeat your enemies
6. spam action button to skip text
7. move your character and spam attack (which is the same as "action") button
8. repeat

conclusion:
It is very easy to like this game: 

Solution #1
you need a few things:
- love anime in general
- remember original game 
- have nostalgia

Solution #2
You haven't played any RPG games before, or played only jRPG games.

Solution #3
You just like easy-going pace of this ... well ... combination of non-interactive story and attack button simulator.

11105306.review:
Ys Origin does a great job explaining the past, it also features interesting characters that you can finish the game with (each one having their own unique game-play, equipment, short storyline and so).

For those who don't know, Ys is an old school action RPG (from the late 80's) that luckily didn't got extinct in today's modern video game industry (That strives to approach to the masses), the surviving series features a very solid and hardcore experience for those who delve in to it (No hands are held here, not suitable for some casual players).

Without delving that much in to the storyline, I'll start by saying that the whole game is set in a massively big tower with tons of floors where you'll actively explore till you reach the top, all because due to the fact you're part of a team that is looking for two mysterious female angel like characters who have disappeared and also they are fighting a mysterious evil that suddenly appeared on their land.

Just like the first of the series, it is based on your character progression (Status), based on your skill and how well prepared and equipped you're, you'll fight tons of different minions and bosses through out the game.

The game is fast paced, if you're used to a slower and less action based game, then do not delve in to this one, you'll have to be quick and prepare yourself to evade any possible attacks and at the same time plan how you'll attack your foes quickly before their defense is up again.

You're forced to play the game to unlock new areas as you progress but do take in mind that you're not only forced to a narrow path, you'll have some freedom of exploration to farm and grab new items. 

As for the game soundtrack you'll be delighted, it is so memorable!
In terms of art style and UI they are all professionally done and will set in motion your connection to the game, giving you a taste of immersion (You'll have a good read, the game has a big script), character wise; some are forgettable but overall your experience with them is quite positive. 

If you like Anime and you like oldschool games that are fast paced and hard, then this is the game for you!

[b]Ein wunderschönes Action-RPG aus dem Hause Falcom.[/b]

Besonders den Soundtrack möchte ich hervorheben. Ys Origin hat - ebenso wie alle anderen Ys-Teile bisher - grandiose Musikstücke, die die jeweiligen Gebiete perfekt untermalen. Mein Lieblingsstück: [url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fhmfUOetWMk]Beyond the Beginning[/url]

The game tells the story of two children(?) whom are traveling with their people to find their deities that seem to have gotten captured. You pick one of the two characters, each offering a "unique" story but ultimately the same main points are hit the same and you play through the exact same levels. What keeps this fresh is that the two characters offer a completely different play style, one is like a tank the other a mage (there's also a third one who plays like a berserker) so there's a little replayability. The stories are mildly interesting nothing ground breaking, it's pretty much every jrpg ever so you climb the tower, find bad guys, things aren't what they seem to be, etc. I'm being a little harsh on the story, many may like it far more than me but after playing games like The Walking Dead and Ni no Kuni it seems lacking in comparision. 
I reccomend this game to any ARPG lovers or JRPG fans in general.

If you made contact with any Ys Game you probably have a good idea what this is about.

10292556.review:
Ys Origin is quite possibly my favorite game on Steam.
It might be because I was already a big fan of the Ys series before I played it, but still! It's a great game.

Ys Origin is an action RPG, with a hack and slash styled battle system. There are 3 playable characters, the 3rd being unlocked when you clear the game the first time with either of the first two characters. Each character has a very specific playstyle. To avoid spoilers, I'll only detail the initial two.

Hugo Fact is a ranged caster. He is very powerful, firing off spell bullets from his wand and his twin artifacts known as the "Eyes of Fact" that hover at his side at all times. His is very agile, but he cannot fire while moving. 

Yunica Tovah is a melee attacker. Armed with her handaxe (and later greatsword), she excels at close combat. She is very quick, dealing fast, hard damage to her opponents. 

When you start the game, you get to choose from many different difficulty settings (Very Easy, Easy, Normal, Hard, Very Hard, Nightmare), as well as choose which character you want to play as. Each character has their own storyline, though all three of them are intertwined. Playing each character is highly recommended, as each storyline offers more and more insight into the overall picture.

Gameplay consists of your typical RPG fare: battling monsters while exploring your surroundings. In Ys Origin, you are tasked with exploring a giant tower that extends to the heavens. The tower is broken up into segments, with each segment offering a different environment to do battle in and explore. They are varied enough to where sometimes you forget you are in a tower and are instead traversing a dungeon located elsewhere. At the end of each segment (and sometimes in the middle) you are presented with a boss. The end of each segment is always a screen-filling boss, and these are the most fun parts of the game, each requiring some strategy to defeat.

Ys Origin includes a neat Arena Bonus Mode and a Boss Rush/Time Attack Mode. In Arena Mode, you choose a character and fight wave after wave of monster in a specific location. As you defeat enemies, you accrue SP. You can then use this SP to unlock a variety of things for this mode, such as extra costumes and even a surprise guest character! In Boss Rush Mode, you can choose to either battle one Boss at a time, or every boss in the game consecutively.

The music and sound effects are top-notch. The Ys series is known for their amazing soundtracks, and Origin is no exception.  After awhile I found myself whistling along as the music played! You may be inclined to find and purchase the soundtrack online...just a warning! :P

Overall this is just an awesome game. I got it on sale for about $7, but in my opinion the original, full price is WELL worth it. You get a lot of game for the price.

[h1][b]Highly Recommended[/b][/h1]

10228039.review:
The Ys series is, from what I recall, one of the big names in the Action RPG circuit, and Ys Origin changes the original formula of the first game (Ys 1 and 2, technically the second being an extension of the first rather than a separate game) by making it more actiony than RPG-y if that makes even the slightest bit of sense (it doesn't).

That being said, this is still a rather fun game to play. The story's nothing to cry home about, but it's engaging enough to make you want to learn more about characters. Basically an okay plot, points for that.

Gameplay is fantastic; three unique characters that each get their own special abilities and varied fighting styles, as well as boss battles that are tailored to their story rather than set bosses (though set bosses still appear). Again, more actiony than RPG-y, but it makes it fun.

The music helps carry the game, since it almost obviously coined the term "rpg combat music". It is literally as generic fantasy-rock as you can get. I swear this is how a music company got its start. The music still helps the game move along.

Overall a rather fun game to play, and one of the few I've played multiple times just to see everything. The other Ys games are about as good, so if you have money to burn, this is worth it, but definitely get it on sale if you can.

9302659.review: Ys Origin isn't for Ys neophytes - it help a lot if you've played Ys I & II before, since you'll get the most out of the story this way (and understand a lot of the references as well). But the game itself is probably the most polished of all the Ys games on Steam. From the silky smooth 60fps gameplay to the surprisingly decent graphics (and pretty impressive bosses), Origin does a great job graphically despite being an older game. The music of couse kicks ass, although I'd put it a notch below the music from Oath in Felghana and Ys I & II. The game is strange in that it doesn't star Adol Christin - instead, three different characters are available to play. To get the most out of the game, you'd need to finish the game with all three characters. In some ways it's rather repetitive since the puzzles and situations don't change much, but the way the characters play differ greatly - especially Hugo, who makes the game almost like a shoot-em-up. Still, it's great to see the story unfold from different perspectives. For Ys fans, this game is a no-brainer - highly satisfying gameplay, good, silky smooth graphics and rocking music. Who could ask for more? 8/10.

Und es gibt die Möglichkeit zu springen (Ich sage nicht welche Tastenbelegung ich habe da sowohl die Steuerung mit Tastatur als auch mit Gamepad einwandfrei funktioniert und alle Tasten frei belegbar sind) Die wahre Stärke des Spiels zeigt sich bei den Bosskämpfen. Diese erfordern meist sowohl eine Taktik als auch ein gutes reaktionsvermögen und stellen schon auf niedrigen aber gerade auf den höheren Schwierigkeitsgraden eine große Gefahr da. Das Spiel an sich kann in wenigen Stunden abgeschlossen werden aber hat einen hohen wiederspielwert durch die verschiedenen Charaktere und einen Boss-Rush modus welcher wohl die Größte herrausforderung darstellt, aber auch diejenigen unter euch, die das Spiel nur einmal durchspielen wollen kommen durchaus auf ihre kosten. 9130579.review: Fantasic game. It's an excellent prequel to Ys 1&2. It does a great job leading into the other games in the series if you've never played them, and ties up all the loose ends if you have played them. All difficulty levels pose some level of challenge, even on the easiest setting, which keeps with the Ys tradition of hair-pulling moments. This game really appeals to me as an avid Ys enthusiast because of all the refernces to Ys 1&2 that aren't story related. Obviously, as a prequel, many story elements have a lot to do with the events of other games, but it's the more subtle references that I enjoy. I especially liked the fact that most of the bosses are from the original games, but the fights are different. I get to see the familiar names and remember my experiences from the original games but have unique and refreshing fights with them. Also, the rendition of "Termination" in this game is completely kickass.

1.  This game is tough, even on the normal difficulty level.  It is not unfair, just tough.

5.   Has some of the most insanely-fun boss battles in recent memory.  (Which the game knows as there is a boss rush mode).

I don't know what else to say.  Great game that takes around 15 hours to complete on normal.

8574072.review:
My score: 9.5/10

I have yet to find anything really wrong with this game.  It plays very much like an old-school RPG but with action elements instead of turn-based combat.  You're slashing, smashing, and magicking your way through a 20-something story tower full of demons.  I don't want to go much into the story because that's half of what makes this game so brilliant.  I haven't played a game with such a great story in a very long time.  Finish this game through to the end as well, because there's a bunch of unlockables (time-attack and an arena battle mode, to name a couple... naming more would be spoilers).  The replay value is pretty good but if you're going for a 100% completion it could take a long while.

Gameplay-wise, it has a few quirks to get used to, and it'll take some time, but once you've got it down it's pretty easy.  The boss battles are INSANE, and there are a LOT.  If you're a fan of great boss fights, you'll love this game.  Each difficulty brings a new attack pattern, etc. to the bosses in addition to basically oneshotting you if you're not properly leveled/geared.

The only qualm I can see that some people might have is that, like I mentioned earlier, if you aren't properly leveled you're going to have a rough time in certain areas of the game (bosses in particular).  The good news is that you'll catch on pretty quick.  The bad news is that you might have to sit there grinding enemies for a while - which isn't too bad, but you have to make sure you save often just in case.

TLDR: Fantastic story, quirky controls, fantastic boss fights, lots of unlockables and decent replay value.  

Pick this game up and if you want more of the story, pick up Ys I & II as well as Oath in Felghana.  All four games are worth it, trust me.

8572073.review:
Как ни удивительно, один из заметных эксклюзивов на PC. Ys Origin содержит все, что славится серия Ys: экшен, исследование локаций, секреты почти в каждой комнате, сложнейших боссов, для победы над которыми нужно отрабатывать тактики до автоматизма. Отвлеклись на решение опциональной загадки или сразились с дополнительными врагами? Получит предмет, упрощающий прохождение. Нет - придется труднее, все логично.

Дополнительно в серию были привнесены возможность выбора направления прокачки персонажа и несколько играбельных героев. Из минусов - пропал персонаж Адол, известный фанатам, но все логично, так как действие происходит за много лет до первой части. Можно поругать и экшен с простыми врагами - это просто сплошное мясо, где нужно лупить по всем кнопкам без всякой тактики, боевой системы по сути в игре и нет.

Тем, кто не знаком с серией, едва ли чем-то зацепит здешний сюжет, но может порадовать анимешный стиль. А вот для фанатов серии, особенной первой части, тут просто тонна отсылок. Все действие игры будет происходить в одной башне Darm (финальной локацией в первой части Ys Eternal), однако разработчики постарались разнообразить все уровни, чтобы народ не заметил однообразия: хватает как огненных, так и водных этапов на все случаи жизни.

Игра довольно хардкорна, обладает 5 уровнями сложностями. Даже на втором у вас будет возникать потребность тщательно подстраиваться под боссов, что же говорить про более высокие.

Графика не поражает воображение, но разработчики добавили несколько фильтров. В любом случае, если вы любитель японских игр, то официальный выпуск Ys Origin в Steam - настоящий подарок.

Приквел к первым двум частям сериала. В целом играется как The Oath in Felghana за тем лишь исключением, что здесь нам дают пройти игру тремя разными персонажами. И когда я говорю "разные", я имею в виду, что это совершенно иной опыт. Меняется не только боевой стиль, но и некоторые события, появляются дополнительные сценки. Чтобы полностью раскрыть сюжет и закрасить белые пятна, нужо пройти игру всеми тремя героями. Помимо этого у каждого из них нередко появляются новые боссы, а старые меняют характер некоторых своих атак. 
Что касается сложности, то у Origin в этом плане все довольно демократично, поэтому выбор варьируется от "очень легкого" до "кошмара", и последний назван не просто так - настоящая игра начинается именно на нем. На "кошмаре" враги не только становятся сильнее, но и атаки у них видоизменяются таким образом, чтобы игроку жизнь медом не казалась. Это относится как как к рядовым противникам, так и к боссам. Впрочем, из всех частей Ys, которые доступны в стиме, в плане драк эта точно самая справедливая. 
Что касается геймплея, то это типичная японская АРПГ, которая полностью состоит из мордобоя. Никаких паззлов и совсем немного бектрекинга. Если сравнивать со слешерами, то тут нет длинного списка открываемых (и часто ненужных) приемов, все предельно просто - стандартная атака, атака, понижающая броню врага, и 3 навыка, которые переключаются одной кнопкой и активируются другой. Самое смешное, что этого хватает с головой, а боссбаттлы настолько динаминчые, что скучно не будет однозначно. Тот случай, когда качество полностью превосходит количество.

8517628.review:
So, an RPG franchise from the 80s-2000s that completely flew under the radar for me until now. Ys Origin, being my very first Ys title makes a VERY great impression on me as not only an RPG obsessed gamer, but a huge fan of the ARPG as a whole. 

Having only experienced Yunica's story thus far, the game itself is beautiful in nearly every way. The art style is what you would expect from the older Final Fantasy games and is greatly complemented by the stellar soundtrack. In fact, during cutscenes during major plot points, the music actually adds a powerful layer of emotion, which really made the game complete for me. The story keeps you wanting more, and you're always itching to progress some more, to see what happens next. 

As for the gameplay, it is nothing but awesome. Even though Origin takes place in one location only, each new floor you ascend to varies from the previous floors, so you never end up feeling bored, or feeling like you're on a slow grind to the summit. Enemies are varied, environments are varied, and nothing really seems to be reused. It's hack n' slash style gameplay is also fast, and furious, and there's little to no downtime between enemy encounters, which keeps the flow of the game fresh and constant, which is a must in an ARPG. 

Boss fights are unlike anything you'll see in today's generation. Boss fights have multiple mechanics to each, and force you to learn the mechanics until you're doing that fight like clockwork. Some boss fights become intense endurance matches, and when you see the boss fall to your feet, the feeling of victory is nothing short of amazing. 

Overall, if you love RPGs, or you're just looking for an intense hack n' slash game that will keep you busy for quite a while (Between playing through all three storylines, time attack, boss rush, and Arena), give Ys Origin a try. You seriously won't regret one moment of it.

I've not got incredibly far in this game but what I've played so far has been a blast. The controls (at least with an XBOX Controller) are tight and responsive, and the combat is very fun.

However, the real treat in this game is the boss fights, which are hella cool and provide a pretty good challenge. I'd recommend a controller because the response time and precision of control you need is so exact. Some of the bosses go into bullet hell territory but many of them require precision jumps and dodges to beat. The common enemies don't really give you too much trouble, but there are areas where combinations of certain types of baddy provide a pretty satisfying clear up.

The graphics are what you'd expect from a small budget Japanese game. They're functional, mostly sprite characters on poly backgrounds and the art style is nice enough if not a little generic. The particle effects are very nice and the fully 3D bosses look fantastic and really show the games artistic strength in full. But you're not really playing this game for the graphics.

All in all I'd recommend it to anyone, especially at a sale price!

8413278.review:
"Ys Origin is a Japanese action role-playing game developed and published by Nihon Falcom for Microsoft Windows in 2006." (Wikipedia, November 2013)

I've played this RPG for 45 hours on the hardest of the 5 difficulties (nightmare, hard, normal, easy, very easy) with "Hugo" (1 of 3 characters) and completed it by level 52. I found the story to be a run-of-the-mill "good guy wants power, turns evil temporarily, and repents through the power of friendship/love". I'm generally not the type of guy to delve into, and enjoy, the story of a game very much anyways, so I didn't mind it. In fact, considering that I look for "great gameplay" in games, and what type of gameplay I'll tend to go for, I would practically expect a story to be "the usual" in a game (not to say I haven't enjoyed original stories). I don't know how the story goes with the other 2 characters, since I haven't played them yet.

This game, played with a top-down camera angle, plays kinda like a shooter when Hugo is the chosen character, as his attacks revolve around shooting magic missiles straight ahead of him. After a quick test run, the other 2 characters appear to revolve around close-range melee combat. On the hardest difficulty level, the bosses offer such a challenge that you'll find yourself grinding a lot, just to gain that extra level or two and be able to defeat the boss at all (and even then, your battle strategy better be near perfect). This game has some simple puzzle-solving, if you can even call it that. You'll find yourself having to press buttons, defeat certain enemies, obtain and use items/skills, and so on. I did enjoy the challenging gameplay, but it would get frustrating at times with bosses, and also 1 time with a certain enemy that can practically insta-kill you (but that you'll still have to deal with). The only thing to do there is keep looking around for equipment and the like, and grind in special spots to gain levels.

If you want to know how nice the graphics look, just "You-Google-Tube" some gameplay footage on the game. And while you're at it, check out the soundtrack for it as well. It's pretty awesome. As of this post, the game is normally $19.99 USD on Steam and I'd say it's worth the price if you love to spend many hours on a challenging "battle-grind" RPG. If it turns-out that you love the game, then you may also love "Ys: The Oath in Felghana", which follows a similar gaming style. You may want to avoid Ys I & II though, which has your main attack revolve around ramming into enemies (like in Hydlide), which ruins any sense of "gameplay" (at least in my opinion).

8347217.review:
Ys Origin is a great example of an Ys title: lots of fun hack-and-slash combat with awesome environments, great boss fights and a killer soundtrack to boot. It's also unique compared to other games in the series due to the fact that you never play as Adol, but rather as two (actually three) other characters, each with their own style of combat. There's Yunica, whose style is the most similar to Adol's, with mid-range combat skills. Then there's Hugo, who's more of a long-distance fighter. And finally, the third character, whose storyline is considered the "canon" one but is also the hardest due to his short-range fighting style. 

Although there are differences between the three, you're still exploring the same dungeon, so it may get repetitive playing as each one. However, doing so helps flesh out the world of Ys further and brings some fun tie-ins to Ys I and II.

The difficulty of the game is well balanced. Normal feels just tough enough but not too much so, making it an enjoyable and rewarding experience. There's also plenty to do for completionists, from beating the game on the highest difficulty (Nightmare) to doing Boss Rushes to Arenas. It'll keep you coming back until you've unlocked all the things and gotten all the Steam achievements. Again, it's hard but not so hard that it seems impossible. 

Overall, I'd recommend this game to people looking for a fun adventure title and are maybe looking to get into the Ys series as a whole. I'd also suggest looking into Ys: The Oath in Felghana, which is equally fun but with more exploration and a shorter game time (which some may prefer).

8344170.review:
Even though Ys Origin is now a relatively old game (it was first released by the end of 2006), it still has plenty to offer to RPG fans:

   - Beautiful graphics, both in-game and cutscenes
   - Simple and intuitive graphic user interface
   - Very fun, rewarding, fast-paced action that hardly gets old
   - Challenging bosses that will make you rethink your playing strategy
   - Not one, nor two... but three different game stories that seemly complement each other

Definitely a great introduction to the Ys series and great improvement from the previously released title, The Oath in Felghana, except maybe in the soundtrack which in my humble opinion lacked that trilling component that made me want to carry on shredding monsters just to keep hearing the track. However, this is more than compensated by the deeply intriguing game stories; more than once I found myself playing an extra hour just to find out what was going to happen next.
Overall, even if you're one of those players that rush through games (which I highly discourage with this one), Ys Origin is guaranteed to give you a good 30+ hours of gameplay any noteworthy action RPG should.

Ys Origin plays like a top-down hack-and-slash but can at times be so frantic it feels like a bullet hell. Think Zelda on steroids. An interesting story, awesome gameplay, and very challenging. Well worth the money and made me purchase the other Ys games - which I am also enjoying.

You are given the choice of playing as a girl with a big axe or a guy with magic. After you beat the game you can go ahead and replay it with the other character or with a new, 3rd character. Playing it with the girl or guy you're first given feels generally the same, although you obviously have an entirely different set of skills. All three characters pretty much trek through the exact same dungeon layout but the 3rd character you unlock fights a set of new bosses and has an entirely different story. Playing on higher difficulties actually changes things besides HP and damage - although the story stays the same.

One downside is that I feel that the leveling was pretty tedius. You will find yourself in positions where you need to grind out 5 levels because it is literally impossible to beat a boss if you don't have the damage output. This only takes maybe 10-15 minutes before each boss but later in the game I remember having to spend an entire hour just beating up 1,000 grunts.

Defintely one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while.

8156380.review:
I am a huge fan of the Ys games.  In my opinion they are overlooked far too often, but I also have a soft spot for a good old hack n' slash so take that with a grain of salt if that isn't your thing.  Ys Origin is a great addition to the Ys series, they don't try anything funny with going waaaay outside the mold but they do some new stuff as well.  It's gameplay is very similar to Ys Seven.  For those that haven't played that it is a pretty simplistic action RPG battle system.  Step1: Hit with weapon and watch numbers pop out, Step 2: Wallop with magic and watch bigger number pop out, Step 3: Grab loot.  This description, while accurate, does not do the game justice by any means as there are several other aspects to battles as well and it isn't always as simple as button mashing to stay alive.

The gameplay is fast paced and there is just enough story to keep you interrested in what is going on, but not so much that you are just mashing your keys to get through dialoge so you can get back to the action.  As per ususal the music is very good and the environments are reminicent of a simpler 2D era of gaming.

Ys Origins is the first time (I think but I could be wrong) that a Ys game has had multiple playable characters.  It is indeed worth it to play through the game with each of them.  I say this because games will often slap an additional caracter on the roster just to extend playtime, but each of these characters plays so differently it feels like a new experience.  Bosses that were a breeze with one person prove very challenging with another, some characters also have different bosses to fight by base. 

The only complaints I have are that 1) Some of the achievements are not hard so much as incredibly time consuming, 2)While the gameplay is very different for each character the story itself does not stray much for each person, though there are subtle differences.  3) In order to experience all the game has to offer in the way of unlockable bonus content and achievements you will need to do a lot of grinding, and by a lot i mean several metric ****loads of grinding.

Play this game if you like: The rest of the Ys series, Hack n' slash, Metroidvania titles (somewhat), grinding, electric guitars in your RPG soundtracks.

8064049.review:
Maybe my biggest surprise / gut purchase ever. Ys is one of those darling series where everyone seems to want to tell you how good it is yet few people have played. While I won't say it's become one of my favorite series, it's become one I've begun to follow, and it along with Trails in the Sky has put Falcom on my mental map when it comes to video games.

Ys, pronounced something like "ease" with only the first letter capitalized and no apostrophe, is basically an action jrpg without random battles or a heavy story emphasis. There's a moderate amount of text dialogue but it's interesting enough and no voice acting to drag it down. Ys Origin is essentially a far prequel to the events of Ys I and II, also available on Steam but significantly more dated. You are given two choices of characters. Yunica provides gameplay more similar to that of series protagonist Adol, specilizing in close combat fighting. Hugo seems to be a more experimental playstyle for the series, focusing on long range magic attacks.

I strongly suggest Yunica to be your first playthrough character for the game. Her playstyle is simply exceedingly more engaging than Hugo, who simply becomes a button spam unless playing at one of the more difficult settings. Luckily to unlock the third character you only need to beat the game as one of these two, which is nice if you want to experience the full canon story of the third character without slogging through a Hugo playthrough. Though you may find you don't mind and will want to play his story anyways.

Ys Origin is a brief experience, which is good considering that if you want to see everything you have to play the game a few times. It also allows for replays and taking on higher difficulties if you find you truly want to master the battle system. While the common enemies may not offer much lateral thought in how you tackle them, the frequent and varied boss encounters are quite a relative spectacle and there's no re-skinning or re-hashing to be seen here. All of them are tackled in a different way.

There is a plethora of music selections for each section of the tower. The whole soundtrack is great an I often found myself humming some of the more memorable tracks. There's also good variety, so finding a few floors with a theme you don't really care for is offset by knowing that a new track is just around the corner.

Definietly consider it if you are looking for a unique jrpg without the bloat that SE or someone like NamcoBandai puts out these days.

8.5/10

8021463.review: A masterpiece of game design and gameplay. This is going to be more a summation of my thoughts rather than a proper review, so here we go. This game does just about everything right, it's a very tightly designed game that's extremely hard to find any flaws in. You can tell they fine tuned and tailored the game for each and every difficulty setting. While more modern games are using cutscenes and CGI as their set pieces, this game uses gigantic bosses that are both creative and challenging. You're almost guaranteed to die a few times before figuring out how they work, which is exactly how bosses SHOULD be. You might find yourself underpowered sometimes, but the game never requires you to do any more than 5 minutes of quick grinding. In fact, if you explore you may not even have to grind. The artwork in this game is amazing, as is the use of colors. It's really nice to have feminine anime characters that aren't at all sexualized for a change. You're consistently unlocking different attacks and using them against enemies whose attack patterns are constantly changing, keeping everything fresh the entire way through. The game even does platforming well, and adds variety to that as well. You're given access to 3 different characters (one you must unlock), and although I'll admit I haven't gotten to the third yet (currently working on beating the game on nightmare mode with all 3 characters, half way through Hugo right now), the game plays remarkably different with each. One is a hack and slash, the other kind of makes the game into a shoot em up believe it or not. Even the achievements, which I usually ignore as I think they're a useless gimmick, are achievements that you'd get through unlocking everything in the game anyway. With the exception of maybe 1 or 2 VERY easy ones, there's no made up fluff like "beat the game in under so and so time" or meaningless things you wouldn't otherwise do. This game really demands to be played with a gamepad in hard or nightmare mode, otherwise it may devolve into carelessly tanking everything and mashing buttons. If you love games, you'd be doing a huge disservice to yourself not to play this excellent game. 10/10

7964387.review:
It's a very linear game and the plot is pretty unoriginal, but executed well enough to make me feel emotionally invested in the later boss battles.  Each level is a 3D puzzle platformer full of hacking and slashing.  Many of the later boss battles become like shoot-em-up/bullet hell games, except that you A: fight melee (if you choose the melee character, which I did), and B: can jump over the bullets.  Each boss requires a nuanced combination of strategies.

The RPG elements are pretty minimal, and the XP system is such that you can't grind ahead of the area's level, but you always catch up the area's level before you reach the boss, even if you try to avoid enemies.  IMO that's a pretty good thing, since it means that there is nothing to distract you from the meat of the gameplay.  (It is vital that you find all of the hidden items, though, at least on hard mode).

Also, while the environments are kinda simple, some of the shader effects look pretty good, the character portrait and sprite art are beautiful, and special effects for character and boss attacks are completely ridiculous (but totally interactive and quite sophisticated; pretty much no scripted execution nonsense).

Oh, and I forgot to mention that the music is fantastic.  I still regularly listen to the soundtrack.

7909671.review:
Fun and positively addictive combat system. Grinding in this game is one of the best grinding experiences in ARPG. Boss battles are tricky and sometimes incredibly brutal, with an upward trend of difficulty in attack patterns and damage received from the first boss to the very last, which is always a crucial key in boss battles design.

Storyline is straightforward and fluid with epic twists (the most literal sense of 'epic'). Covers most of the important key points that explain what happens in the main series, while also leaves very much room for personal interpretation and possibly retelling. 

Character designs are surprisingly intricate and interesting, considering the fact that Falcom had always been set with simplicity in all Ys titles until Ys Origin came out in 2006.

Not much needs to be said about the music. Falcom JDK Band did a fantastic job as usual. I believe the music in Ys Origin is about as well-praised as that of Oath in Felghana. Beyond the Beginning is personally my favorite track.

The only potential problem with the game is everything stays the very same throughout all three arcs, except for character combat mechanics, storyline, and minor spoiler: a true final boss. This can be boring to some people, but not to me personally.

Overall, this is definitely a very solid and highly polished dungeon-crawler ARPG from Falcom, and a worthy title to mark the big jump of the series to Ys Seven. Absolutely a huge Yes from me.
