7875216.review:
[h1][Description][/h1]
Ys Origin is a Japanese action RPG that is a prequel to it's many previous installations in the Ys franchise, taking place 700 years before the events of the original. You can choose between three playable characters with their own distinctive combat style and skills and each one of them offers a different story perspective. This is also the very first YS game without Adol Christin being the protagonist.

[h1][The Game’s Strengths][/h1]
- A good story to introduce you into the world of Ys
- Three storylines with different characters which show you different perspectives
- Different characters also use completely different skills and weapons
- Fast paced and challenging action combat
- Four difficulties with the higher ones being a real challenge
- Decent amount of challenging boss fights
- The option of grinding monsters until bosses become manageable
- Simple and easy to understand controls, best played with a controller
- Clean yet beautiful 2D rendered environments that have a 3D feel
- Character sprites in gorgeous pixel style
- Memorable soundtrack that will stick to you even after you have finished the game (I highly recommend checking out the YS Origins super arranged version)
- Boss Rush, Time Mode, Arena Mode
- 15 to 35 hours of playtime depending on your playstyle

[h1][Outro][/h1]
Certainly one of the best action RPGs on steam and despite it's age, is still hella good looking. I recommend this game to any fan of the YS franchise and JRPG fans in general. Also make sure to check out all the other YS games already available on steam.

7813940.review:
God damnit, this game makes me happy.

If you've ever played "Secret of Mana", the Japan-only released "Seiken Densetsu 3" or even Supergiantgames' "Bastion", you pretty much know what to expect from Ys Origin. This is old-school, balls-to-the-walls hack'n'slay action and it is glorious.

Combat feels smoth and responsive (as long as you avoid playing as Hugo), the story is cheesy and fun without getting too silly or taking you out of your comfort-zone. You also don't really need to play any previous games to understand what the hell is going on, which is always nice. Boss battles are without a doubt the highlight of the game and especially the "duels" with enemy warriors and mages are extremely well-made and memorable in every way. As is the soundtrack, even when it still sounds like really-badly-made-MIDI-file.

This game is EXTREMELY linear. Most chests contain mandatory character upgrades and even branching hallways are few and far between. Also, if you are the type of person that is easily bored by a single activity, Ys is probably not for you (although the game tries it's best to mix things up every now and again, to varying success).  

For those of you not put off by those things, Ys Origin is a wonderul throwback to simpler times. I can't promise you'll enjoy it but I sure did.

7807230.review:
I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/07/ys-origin.html

What sets this game apart?
The Ys series has been a popular action RPG franchise since 1987, but has only had limited release in the US.  Ys Origin serves as a prequel to the rest of the series chronologically, but is one of the most recent releases in the series.    While the combat sometimes seems more like a hack-and-slash action game than an RPG, there is a sense of strategy and patience required in some areas, especially boss fights, which maintains a more cerebral element in the game.  In addition, there are some good platforming sequences and simple puzzle elements that add enough variety to keep the game from feeling monotonous by breaking up the combat sequences.

What is the difficulty factor?
This game is extremely simple to pick up and play.  It features the choice of mouse and keyboard controls featuring point and click movement, or you can control your character with just the keyboard when more precision is needed.  Personally, I only use the mouse when I have a slice of pizza in my left hand.  When new powers are unlocked, brief tutorial screens pop-up to explain their use, and most of them feel fairly intuitive anyway.  The game also does a fairly good job of offering direction, feeling fairly linear except for a few brief moments, often due to dialogue from the NPCs.

With that being said, this game is not without its challenging points.  The bosses tend to be extremely powerful, at least until you master the patterns of their attacks.  Even then, they require some precision movement and possibly some level grinding to survive.  For those familiar with the bullet-hell genre, you may find yourselves following a familiar strategy of focusing on not getting hit, only taking attacks when you have the rare opportunity.  The rest of the game is fairly tame, although if you let yourself get impatient or careless you will likely end up dying.  Save often.

Does it use media effectively?
I feel a bit torn regarding the visuals of this game.  The cut scenes use a great mix of 3-D and anime style graphics and are usually gorgeous to look at.  The hand drawn character art used during dialogue is on par with many other games, although the character designs feel a bit stale, like you’ve seen them all used before.  The sprites for the characters have an odd, compressed feel to them, looking more like dwarves than the anime style drawings used outside of gameplay.  The game also uses an odd semi-locked camera at three-quarter view, but the level designs do a good job accounting for this.

The music in this game is phenomenal, playing on both the classical and rock aspects of traditional game music to keep every fight intense.  One thing that struck me was the lack of voice acting in the game, which I feel could have done a lot to enhance the overall experience of the game, especially during some of the longer cut scenes that can break the momentum of the game.

Best moment in the game?
Without a doubt, the star of Ys Origin is the boss fight experience.  Every boss fight seems bigger and more epic than the last, and each one requires better timing and more complex movement to follow its pattern.  Off hand, I really enjoyed the giant centipede boss, Nygtilger, playing as Yunica.  It wasn’t necessarily the hardest boss, but the amount of movement and explosions, coupled with the amount of time you spend climbing on it made it a really fun experience.

Who needs to play this game?
While it doesn’t have as many exploration or story elements as many other games of this genre, Ys Origin’s saving grace are its gameplay and music.  Each character has a very different feeling to its playthrough, including some alteration of the level design and especially the bosses, greatly increasing the playtime on this game.  With scalable difficulty and already difficult bosses, it can also prove a suitable challenge for players seeking it, or to encourage subsequent playthroughs.  Personally, while I enjoyed the game, I am glad I picked it up while it was on sale.  If it sounds like your cup of tea, I would wait for the next Steam sale to roll around to pick it up.

7742912.review:
Well here we are a few days into June 2012, and the gaming year couldn't be going better.. E3 is in full swing, with publishers announcing their latest and greatest titles. However quite frankly I'm finding myself distracted from all the excitement. Why, do you ask? It's because I have found my personal Game of The Year, and I don't think anything else that could come out right now could possibly top it. You can take your Diablos, your Modern Warfares, your Max Paynes, and you can file them all away for some other time and place. I'm too busy saving the ancient land of Ys from demonic hordes hellbent on the destruction of humanity!

It has been a mere three months since XSEED made their Steam debut with the smash hit Ys: The Oath in Felghana. In that short time their crack squad of programming gurus and translation wizards have been working overtime to bring us more Ys goodness, and this time they've takes us back to the beginning with Ys Origin. This entry in the series is actually a prequel, taking place 700 years before the events of the first Ys games. This of course means that Adol Christin has to sit this round out, however do not despair! This time around we have THREE playable characters to fill out the roster, and each of them brings their own story and unique gameplay style to the table.

If you have played a Ys game before (and I'm sure you have) then you should feel right at home with Yunica Tovah, our first playable character. She's a tough but compassionate young girl who has dedicated her life to protecting the goddesses. Do not underestimate her abilities because although she cannot use magic, she can swing around a massive battle axe as if it were a feather duster. Players new to the series should start with Yunica, as she is very easy to handle in combat. Once players feel comfortable they can tackle Hugo Fact, a magic user who plays out like a bullet hell shooter. The third (and secret) character will unlock once you finish the game as either Yunica or Hugo, and suffice it to say he's only for experienced players.

Of course it would not be an Ys game if it didn't have big badass boss fights, and Ys Origin delivers in spades! As usual each boss has it's weak point and a pattern that you can exploit, and half the fun is figuring out how! Unlike other games that have impossibly punishing bosses, in Ys Origin if you're dying frequently you can simply level up and try again. Also be sure to check out the upgrade menu at save points, though they may seem minor, the right enhancement can save your life. Also be on the lookout for rare cleria ore, as it can be used to temper your weapons.

The music and graphics are of course as stunning as you would expect from a series of such a high caliber as Ys. From the stirring violin strains of the opening theme which give way to choral chants and guitar riffs, you can guess from just that track alone that the soundtrack is something special. And it truly is, with a wildly diverse soundscape of orchestral music inlaid with the finest hair metal that Falcom Sound Team J.D.K. has to offer. Just ad rich are the gorgeously rendered 3d backgrounds and lush sprites that make up the visuals.

After you finish the main quest in Ys Origin there's still plenty to do. A host of unlockables including Time Attack, Boss Rush, and Arena modes round out the package, offering hours of gameplay beyond the main story. If you yearn for an epic story with brutal bosses, complex character development, and a truly hardcore soundtrack, look no further than Ys Origin. Newcomers will find an engaging start to a new series, and Ys veterans will find plenty of references to their beloved series, and even answers to some burning questions that they may have. At a solid asking price of $20, Ys Origin is an unbeatable value. Pick it up today!

7741340.review:
YS Origins, a lost gem among rpg's?

Ys Origins is a prequel to a series named Ys which I had never even heard of, which I was suprised considering my love of rpg's. Ys Origins feels a lot more like a very fast legend of Zelda title mixed with a dungeon crawler, as in you navaigate dungeons while solving puzzles and killing a lot of enemy demons rather than a Final Fantasy type game with it's turn based battle mechanics. The game consists of three characters Yunica, Hugo and Toal, the game must be completed once to unlock Toal.

The three characters have very different distinct play styles and abilities which really makes the game feel fresh even though you are revisiting the same areas each time, also each time you will see a different side to an interesting story. The entireity of the game is spent climbing a tower, with your surroundings, traps and enemies varying from floor to floor.  You will solve puzzles while fighting hundreds of demons which will give you experience to level up to get stronger and sp to enhance other abilities. 

Along with the three characters the game also contains a time trial mode that times your climb of the tower and an arena mode which you fight waves of monsters increasing the replay value, which you can unlock other versions of the three characters and the main character from the other Ys games.

Enemies are very varied, but every few floors you will face a gigantic boss, the boss's are very challenging needing different tactics each time and extremely rewarding when you finally finish it off. 

I really enjoyed playing it as all three characters and will be purchasing the other ys games on steam and reviewing those too. 

Pros
- Nice graphics feeling retro and new at the same time
- Interesting storyline and characters
- Lots of replay value
- Fun gameplay
- Very action packed
- Amazing boss fights

Cons
- No world map, entirely in the tower
- The inside of the tower barely changes for each character
- Some of the steam achievements didnt seem to unlock although im sure I met the criteria

Overall Score
9/10

7363032.review:
First things first - I had no idea what this game was about when I bought it. It was cheap in a Steam Sale, and I thought 'Hey why not - lol backlog'. However, times are a changing, and it's no longer about buffing that backlog game count, but actually PLAYING GAMES. 

Yes, playing games. On steam.

So, having finally gotten around to playing this game (thanks to Steam Roulette), I have to say I'm genuinly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. It's a simple RPG/Adventure game, with some very basic yet effective hack'n'slash mechanics. While it would be wrong to say it's similar to Devil May Cry in the way that the combat is simple, but at the same time a little frantic, it does help paint a similar picture. 

The most rewarding part of the entire experience are the Boss Battles. They're old school - patterns & phase based, rather than just being normal mobs with a crazy amount of HP, dealing insane damage. Nope, no spank'n'tank here - these bosses have patterns of attacks, and phase of attacks based on their HP. Classic. 
They're frustrating to the point of fanfare when you finally take them down, which is great. 

Games tend to skip over the challenge and frustration these days, which means gamers miss out on learning, resilience and fist pumping when they finally topple the twat that's blocked their way for the last hour. This game doesn't deny you that pleasure. 
I feel like I'm not really doing the game justice - if you're still unsure there are 10/11 youtube videos linked to my Steam Account of my playthrough, so you could always check those out too. 

Ultimately, give it a go and you might surprise yourself.

4055780.review: If you enjoy playing action role-playing games (particularly those from Japan), Ys Origin is a solid investment.  At first, the level designs and monsters were fairly basic, but this is not so much of an issue as you progress higher up the tower.  The amount of variety in the demon designs and floor designs later on isn't spectacular, but keep in mind this is all going on inside of a tower.  The bosses--I would say--are the only exception.  The level and skill system revolve around finding new equipment and gems.  Although simple in design, there is just enough variety to keep you interested.  The story itself is alright (at least to the point where I am at...), and the characters aren't too bad.  You won't be interacting with them too much anyway.  In order to improve your character's own abilities and the abilities of some of your weapons and other equipment, the game allows players to cash in the SP dropped by defeated demons.  This SP is cashed in at the game's Goddess statues, which also serve as save points.  Generally, the distance between these save points is just the "right" distance.  If you don't know what difficulty to play at, I would recommend the "normal" difficulty setting.  Normal might seem too easy at first, but the game becomes significantly harder later on.  However, action RPG veterans will likely want to bump up the difficulty a notch or two.  If not at the normal price, then consider adding Ys Origin to your Steam library the next time the game is on sale.

2873840.review:
Can't really place why Origin stands out as my favourite in the Ys series, but it just does. The gameplay is fast, fun and fluid and the boss fights are challenging yet rewarding. Youre standard enemies are easy to kill and don't provide much of a challenge at all, they really only exist to grind if you want to when the bosses start kicking you ass. Three main story characters, all of which have unique fighting styles and individual stories, really help to make the game feel whole.

On their own, the stories are jagged and a bit weak. The writing is VERY amateurish in my opinion, but that adds to the charm of the game. The sometimes hilariously bad dialogue makes it feel as though you're playing through an early 90's anime, but the incredible combat makes up for it. 

It's a fast paced game but definitely not for everyone. If you're hesitatnt, i'd recommend checking out some gameplay footage or waiting until it goes on sale.

If you liked Ys: Oath in Felghana, you'll almost certainly like Ys: Origin. It uses the same game engine, but with gameplay improvements. There are three characters to play as, with different fighting styles - while Yunica plays much like Adol, Hugo is an entirely different style with a very simple basic attack but more interesting skills, requiring better and more frequent use of them with a more defensive play style.

All the usual highlights of an Ys game come back too - polished art, rockin' music, metroidvania-type exploration, and interesting bosses. Definitely worth it, but if you're still unsure, there's a demo you can try.

Falcom decided to revisit the Darm Tower from the first Ys game (and you even visit it again in Ys IV: Dawn of Ys), so while it's a barebones concept on paper, they actually reinvented the mazelike floors of the Tower wonderfully. For the first time in the series, you can play with different characters (Adol is still in the game, don't worry) and the music proves once again how this series can brag with having one of the finest scores in video game history.

Sadly, in order to understand the full story, you have to go through the game with all three characters, which doesn't sound bad at all, but you still go through the same places three times and that can get boring.

1847228.review:
It's a pretty decent hack'n'slash ARPG, if that's all you're looking for, but it doesn't particularly stand out unless you're there for the Ys part of it. The combat is solid but doesn't have a ton of depth. The characters are likable but don't have a ton of depth. The story is your standard "bad guys did something bad; now the good guys better do something about it" fare, so it won't carry anything on its own (not to mention it only shows up for a few minutes of exposition every hour or so). It would be a fairly satisfying little timekiller that doesn't really stand out in any way except for one thing: a lot of the unlocks feel like they're on a free-to-play schedule in a non-free-to-play game.

The higher tier upgrades in the story mode take an absurd amount of grinding to pay for. Can't beat a boss? Grind some levels, because a single level's worth of stats will make an enormous difference in the damage you deal/take. Two levels will change a fight from brutally hard to a pushover (although that's more "return of the 90s" than "when free-to-play games attack"). There are a bunch of bonus game modes you can unlock and extra characters and alternate character versions with different attacks and all sorts of stuff like that, but they require beating the entire story mode so many times (and weirdly, most of the achievement requirements are also "beat the game multiple times") that I'm guessing at least 90% of people will never even see things like arena mode. I know I certainly won't, even though I'd try it out if it were available immediately after having beaten the game the first time. It makes Korean MMOs look like they're concerned that you don't get outside enough.

Aside from that, it's fun enough, but I'd mostly only recommend it to people who want more backstory to the Ys games.

5477677.review: Ys Origin is one of the greatest action RPGs ever made.  Unless you hate action RPGs with great combat, bosses, characters and interesting narrative you should play Ys Origin.

2925952.review: Un gran bel gioco. Dove almeno personalmente il difetto è uno solo, il leveling alla lunga può diventare ripetitivo e frustante. Per il resto è solo un continuo salire. Più prosegui nella trama e più ne rimani coinvolto. E soprattutto, molto intelligente la scelta di farti scegliere prima di iniziare il gioco con quale personaggio preferisci iniziare. Non solo non cambiano alcuni dialoghi, ma una volta finito il gioco, ti dà perfino la possibilità di giocare col cattivo di turno e vedersi l'intera storia nella sua prospettiva. E inoltre ogni personaggio ha le proprie abilità ben diversificate, ogni stile di combattimento è diverso, invogliandoti a rigiocare il gioco e affrontare i boss in una maniera completamente diversa. Inoltre i vari personaggi sono tutti caratterizzati bene, nessuno è banale, e tutti hanno il proprio bel background, infatti il gioco presenta alcuni flashback e alcuni dialoghi un po' lunghi, ma non pesanti, tutti utili al fine della storia. Inoltre altro punto fondamentale di questo gioco. L'OST. L'OST è composta solo da tracce memorabili, dalla prima fino all'ultima, infatti mi ha invogliato a procurarmela e di inserirla nel mio telefono il prima possibile. Come gameplay, è un mix di Platform/RPG/Hack and Slash. Tutto confezionato in un modo ottimale, un gameplay abbastanza semplice però efficacie, che rende il titolo mai noioso e sempre giocabile. Soprattutto rigiocabile grazie alle abilità diverse dei vari protagonisti che si vuol scegliere prima della fine del gioco. E poi i boss. I boss sono tutti diversi, tutti difficili, dove c'è bisogno di fare attenzione che anche la minima cazzata vi può compromettere l'intero combattimento. Infatti mi è capitato di morire assieme al boss, e di fare vari ragequit, ma una volta battuti, vi verrà voglia di stappare lo spumante. Infine è un gioco che non mi sentirei a consigliare a tutti, perché la trama è fin troppo "giapponese" e quindi per qualcuno può far storcere il naso. Si parla di Dee, maghi, cavalieri sacri e quant'altro, magie demoniache e robe così. E si perde in qualche momento che per alcuni non potranno risultare emozionanti per niente. Però dall'altro canto se non vi potrà piacere per la trama, di sicuro vi piacerà per il gameplay. Fidatevi, la semplicità del gameplay vi farà tenere incollati allo schermo.

6572677.review:
The Ys (prounounced Ees) series has long ben one of the finer series in Japanese action RPGs. It has been known for being one of the first game series to emphasize story, its brutal bosses,   fantastic rock soundtrack.....and barely ever being imported into the U.S. My own only experience with the series was Ys III, released in 1991, on the Sega Genesis

Ys Origins is a surprisingly polished game, considering its original release in 2006. With a focus on combat and dungeon exploration, the game feels familiar, but is polished enough to stay entertained enough through its campaign.

And what a campaign. Though a single character's story line is no longer than 8 to 9 hours, Ys Origins provides 3 different characters, each with a completely different fighting style, viewpoint in the story, and even differences in area accessability and boss battles. Combined with bonus time attack and boss rush modes, where devoted players can earn special costumes, battles, and even a bonus character, Ys Origin can easily be enjoyed for over 30 hours. 

Ys Origin is not without flaws. The story is serviceable, but fairly predictable. Some later boss battles can be an exercise in frustration, and you'll wish that they mixed up the dungeons a bit more between characters. However, for anyone looking for a classic, rewarding, challenging action RPG with all of the Japanese trappings, you can do a lot worse than this artifact of the previous decade.

4385792.review:
Ys Origin from Nihon Falcom is a Japanese take on the ARPG genre, so it's a JARPG I guess. I didn't really know what to expect when I started playing it but I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. The combat is solid and the graphics are charming.  Although you aren't given free reign to upgrade your character like a Western ARPG you level up as you kill monsters which strengthens your stats and you also gain SP by killing monsters which you can use to purchase upgrades for your character to increase passive stats such as Mana Cost for spells. Grinding is also well done in this game, if you kill the monsters as you advance through the game your character will be strong enough to defeat the bosses; however, if you're having trouble with a particular enemy you can grind up to increase your stats if you wish. Speaking of bosses, it was the best part about the game. The boss fights are well designed, challenging, but also fair. It's kind of a "find the pattern" type of deal, but there's a lot of skill involved in defeating the many bosses in the game. It had a Demon's Souls type of feel for the boss battles but the rest of the game had a Zelda-esque feel to it. The bosses were so fun I thought to myself while playing, "it would be awesome if this game had a boss rush mode." Little did I know, it does! It unlocks after you beat the game.

While I enjoyed the game a lot, it did have a few problems. The game is linear, with you having to find a key or item to get to the next area and there isn't an open world as you're just going up a tower. That's not to say the environments aren't varied, as they are, it just means there isn't much exploring to do. There's also a bit too much backtracking for my taste, but it wasn't too excessive. The music is pretty low quality and repetative and the control settings aren't adjustable in-game (you have to use a separately loaded launcher) so if you don't have your controller settings set properly you have to exit the entire game to get it right; other than that the controller support in the game is quite good. 

There are three playable characters (one of which is unlockable), each of which gives you a different point of view on the narrative. The unlockable character is actually a demon as well, so you get the antagonist's point of view on the story which I found quite cool. The story itself is rather tropey, but still was a little more adult than other JRPGs I have played (it has swear words and death) which I enjoyed. The game loads and exits in a snap, which is also a plus.

Pros:

Gameplay
Storyline (multiple perspectives)
3 Characters that play quite differently
"Grinding" done well for a JRPG
Boss Fights
Unlockables and Bonus Modes (with leaderboard support!)
Excellent Replayability

Cons:

Music/Audio
Backtracking
Linearity

I really enjoyed this Japanese take on the ARPG genre. If you enjoy killer boss fights I'd recommend it for you. There's also a boss rush mode which is amazing for this game and many other unlockables to keep your interest in the game after you've beaten it. The three available characters all play differently and show you a different perspective on the events of the story and I'm really looking forward to coming back and playing this game again once I've finished the other games in my collection. There are a few negative aspects of Ys Origin (I really disliked the audio engineering) but they don't overbearingly detract from the fun I had with this game. A-

NOTE: I did play Ys Oath in Felghana and I have to say I wasn't as impressed with that game as I was with this one.  The boss battles weren't as epic, grinding felt more necessary, the music was better (but still repetetive), and basically everything that was good about that game is in Origin, but there's a lot missing.  The protagonist is also silent (which hasn't been cool since Freeman did it), and there's only one playable character.  I would NOT recommend Oath, but Origin is great.  If you want more of the same gameplay, play the other characters on Origin - skip Oath unless you REALLY love the series.

5205504.review:
If you're in to (japanese) Action-RPG's and like a great challenge when it comes to boss fights, I highly recommend Ys: Origin. There are 3 different playable characters with their own playstyles and multiple difficulties to choose from. The basic "grinding" and leveling system is fun and addictive. You'll just want to keep slaying enemies after another, before your accumulating +exp, +str and +mana regen meters run off. The levels have puzzles and ofc treasures aswell, so it's not all brainless grinding (though you still can't turn your brain off while leveling, it's easy to die to normal mobs unless you pay attention). The level designs are nice aswell, there's enough to explore and it's not linear at all.

But the best part of Ys: Origin are the hard boss battles. (If you're experienced in this kind of genre, I recommend either Hard or Nightmare difficulty to make the best out of the fights) The boss tactics are quite varied, though many resembled me of Touhou games, just in 3D. In other words there's quite a lot of projectiles to avoid, and you can't take too many hits. The fights usually take some time to learn to execute good enough, but beating the boss in the end is a great feeling.

The story isn't anything fancy unfortunately, so better not get your hopes up on that. Music on the otherhand is great, not the best of the best among the J-RPG composers, but still great. I love those upbeat tunes that play during the boss battles, they make the fights feel even more epic!

The graphics are really outdated, since the orginal game was released in 2006. The characters are drawn as sprites, but the enviroment is in 3D and looked from an isometric perspective. Though, the game kind of has an old-school feel with it because of this, and it might not be a bad thing. But if you're bothered by the old look, this game is not propably for you.

763512.review: This game is all about the bosses, and most of them are pretty entertaining to fight and are challenging as well. It's the game Falcom made after Oath in Felghana. The combat system is even more polished, the boss battles even more crazy, the music even more fantastic (in places), and the player characters even more talkactive. While it lacks an overworld it doesn't skimp on providing an interesting and varied labyrinth to go through. 
If you haven't bought Oath in Felghana yet, you should. If you haven't, you'll find what I wrote above (in parts) easy to believe! Origin improves on the amazing gameplay of its predecessor, while adding more to be awed at! And it's a real PC exclusive game!
As before, though, might be too hardcore for some. Graphics were good for their time, but aren't spectacular now. You don't need to care about the story.

4221792.review:
Many have dismissed Ys Origin as a cheap cash in game, a place holder between other, more successful games. Yet I'm not one of those; sure, it's basically Ys I&II: The Before Years, but that's EXACTLY why I enjoy the game. Ys as a series has been sorely lacking in back story; many key events in the past have been teased by Falcom, yet we've never seen them. Ys Origin, thankfully, does the job of offering us SOME insight to the history of the flying island, several bosses/main villains of Ys I&II and, finally, the reason why the Goddesses of Ys lost their wings.

Even though Oath of Felghana and even Ark of Napishtim are better in certain aspects, Origin IS NOT in any way truly inferior to them. It has the same great engine and game play of the others, and despite, or perhaps maybe in spite of the fact that it's all contained within Darm Tower, Ys Origin earns its place in my heart for giving me precious back story that's been so scarce.

Oh, and Adol is unlockable. JOY!

>Girl expert at close quarter combat
>Guy expert at magic and long range attacks
Seems legit.

Mismatching aside, this is one of my favorite games. The boss battles are pretty hard -- there are no healing spells or resurrecting potions to keep you going. You have to be careful and dodge every attack and in Nightmare mode, the bosses are very durable. It takes patience, quick reflexes and level grinding isn't really that bad. This game also inspired me to revisit the good RPGs of the SNES and PS1 era. Chrono Trigger, here I come!

27857.review: Delightfully old-school action-RPG. Isometric view, 2D sprites on a 3D background, and fast-paced button-mashing combat. It can be rather challenging on the higher difficulties, where bosses both massive and man-sized will repeatedly deliver you a taste of the afterlife. The story drives the action nicely and sets up for the events of Ys I&II, but it's not the most memorable tale ever told. The real soul of Ys Origin is in smashing 50-foot bosses using your trusty adolescent girl with a giant axe and conveniently-placed magical artifacts. With 3 playable characters (and you'll probably want to play through the game with each) and a more than ten-hour campaign, Ys Origin gives you a lot of bang for your buck. Or, rather, a lot of slash, smash, and pew-pew for your buck.

3634030.review: A solid piece of hack-and-slash platformery (is that even a word?)  with rpg elements thrown in. The graphics leave a little to be desired- I recommend watching the trailer to see if they're your cup of tea- and the story is a tad cliche, but that doesn't stop Ys Origin from being a fun-filled romp. The adjustable difficulty levels make the game accessible to casual gamers and hardcore fans alike, and the multiple character choices make this game more replayable than the previous Ys title released on Steam, Oath in Felghana. In fact, if you want to see what the Ys series is all about, this is a good game to start with. A word of caution for the uninitiated- the boss fights are old-school, learn-how-this-thing-can-kill-me-by-dying -to-it-repeatedly encounters, especially on any difficulty above easy; then again, the boss encounters are part of the game- and the series'- charm. Is it an amazingly designed game, worthy of critical accolades? No. Is it enjoyable? Definitely.

3571849.review:
Previously cleared this prequel of YS  when the original Japanese version was released for PC, but purchased and cleared again for nostalgia when it was re-released on Steam. 

Gameplay (as stated in another review of YS) is action-RPG'ish (resembling both Zelda and Diablo), as the player controls the main character from an overhead third person view. Characters can be unlocked within the game, offering up to 4 (one is unofficially unlocked) different selections each with their own types of skill sets. Characters can level up and acquire a set of sword-skills and magic to demolish enemies that are encountered throughout the game. Storyline is paced well, but can be tedious to understand, as the lore of YS is quite deep in this version of the game. Must play as all three storyline characters to completely understand each of their motives. 

Music is also amazing, setting the tone of each and every stage the character enters. Graphics are outdated by modern standards, but the gameplay and music completely allow the user to forget about it. 

Played through the entire game with all three characters (Yunica/Hugo/Toal).

Highly recommend. 5 out of 5 stars.

1827143.review:
This action RPG drips "old-school" from its pores. While the series never caught on big in the US during its original releases, these remakes and rereleases are worth a look.

There isn't any variation or customization in your character progression, other than the order in which you buy some passive upgrades, so the game will succeed or fail by the gameplay itself. It mostly succeeds here, if you liked Secret of Mana and similar games. There's a great soundtrack to keep you going as well.

So what's old-school about it? Two things stand out: the punishing bosses and the level grind. You'll NEED to pick out the boss patterns to beat them. If you're not stopping to spill some extra blood as you play through the game, you'll be underleveled and you will die quickly. This can even happen on normal monsters - if you find yourself dealing weaksauce damage to new monsters, when you used to be cleaving through armies, go back and grind a few levels. Comparative level matters a lot.

A fun Action-RPG with multiple character with different play styles, an enjoyable storyline and extra game modes. With the bosses and difficulties giving you a constant challenge, it's definitely not a game you can just plow through. Good loot is scattered across the tower that require you to use your wits and abilities to obtain.

Each character tells a pretty similar story from their point of view. So the replay value is pretty nice. You start off with 2/4 characters and unlock the others (with their EX versions) after some rewarding hard work.

Overall, this game is worth the money. It's fun to see a game that isn't 100% easy all the time nowadays.

1985664.review:
Ys Origin is an Japanese-style action RPG, set as a prequel to the Ys series. This is the first Ys game I've played, and I've definitely been enjoying it.

The game's combat system is the best part of it: normal enemies don't give you much of a challenge because they're easily stun-locked (as Yunica, at least), but the boss battles are intense. The bosses are difficult and they take a while to bring down even if you know what you're doing, but their attacks are easily predicted. It does take some skill to get through it, though (on Normal). The game's story and world are also interesting; it has one of the better game stories I've seen recently.

This game is definitely worth considering for any RPG fan, and I would recommend it even at full price to fans of the genre.

1543732.review: Wer glaubt, dass alle guten Action-Adventure gestorben sind, die aus den Zeiten des Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) stammen, der hat noch nicht gemerkt, dass es dieses Spiel gibt. Ys Origin ist ein hervorragender Nachfolger der Ys Saga, der sozusagen in den Anfang von allem in Ys selbst spielt. Dabei wurde das System genutzt, das schon in Ys Seven oder Ys – The Ark of Napishtim und anderen Titeln verwendet wurde. Pure Action, eine kleinere, aber doch durchdachte und interessante Story und hervorragender OST machen das Spiel zu einem interessanten Erlebnis. Die Grafik mag zwar für manche etwas angestaubt wirken, aber gleichermaßen ist sie ziemlich schnell und läuft vorteilhafter Weise selbst auf älteren Systemen problemlos. Eine echte Empfehlung für jene, die mal etwas Neues, Altes ausprobieren wollen, oder alte Veteranen sind. P.S.: Unbedingt den OST der Serie anhören, der vom Falcom Sound Team jdk geschrieben und sogar für Alben neu aufgelegt wurde!

62771.review:
A fun and fast-paced action JRPG similar to Castlevania. You gain very temporary stat boosts every time you kill an enemy so it rewards you for playing at breakneck speed which is very satisfying. 

The overall plot is a bit generic but the dialogue itself is absolutely fantastic. The exchanges between the characters feels very natural and interesting. It is also free of the unintentional awkward moments that JRPGs tend to have due to sloppy translations. 

The game is of about medium length for an action game, about 10-15 hours on hard mode. However  you are able to play through multiple times as different characters to get a different perspective on the story and each has a unique style of fighting. 

The graphics are a little dated and look like they belong on the Playstation 2 but that's a minor fault. 

Lastly, the game is clearly designed to be played on a gamepad. You can play with the keyboard and mouse but it's sort of clumsy.

Set almost a millenium before Ys I, Origin poses many questions: what happened to the seas of water, lava, toxic blood and the entire desert stuck inside the Devil's Tower between games, and where could they ever possibly go? With his magical Gradius options, main character Hugo Fact is prepared to solve these mysteries with none of the usual conditions for success required of other lesser protagonists, such as being limited by range, having to follow a set attack progression and not just fill the screen with an endless torrent of projectiles that eventually causes the overwracked sound driver to start playing effects half a second late, and actually taking damage when hit. Buy Ys Origin and be a wizard today!

39835620.review:
As of writing this review, Ys Origin is probably my favorite game in the series. Granted, I've still yet to play Memories of Celceta (hoping for a PC port!) and Lacrimosa of Dana (hoping the PC port isn't gonna be vaporware!), but I still prefer it over more celebrated titles in the series like Oath in Felghana and SEVEN. The final entry in the "Napishtim/Felghana trilogy", Origin takes place 700 years before the first Ys game, giving us a much broader history of the setting of the first two games.

Instead of our usual red-haired swordsman, Origin starts giving players the choice between two characters. Yunica Tovah is the granddaughter of one of the six priests of Ys and fights with an axe -- she plays similarly to Adol. Then there's Hugo Fact -- the son of another priest -- who fights with magic, flanked by two orbs that multiply his attacks: the "Eyes of Fact", a family keepsake. Both characters were sent down as part of a search party to the surface from the floating continent of Ys after the two goddesses, Feena and Reah, go missing one day. Unfortunately, they're attacked and separated by a mysterious attack, falling unconscious as they fall to the surface. There, they find Darm Tower, a gigantic ziggurat seemingly built by the monsters that have taken over the land. Informed that the goddesses were seen entering the structure by the twin Roda Trees, our heroes set off on a journey to find the missing goddesses and find out what purpose Darm Tower serves.

Since Felghana refined the gameplay to perfection, Origin doesn't really change much in terms of the game's engine. The entire game takes place within Darm Tower, essentially cutting out the game's overworld segments. However, the settings in the Tower itself are pretty diverse, ranging from a desert with slippery gold floors, a volcano and even an underwater segment -- significantly more extravagant than it was in the original Ys. A lot of the bosses from the first game (and one from the second) return, somewhat reimagined in a much more epic state.

The graphics are much like the two previous games, but I still think Origin is gorgeous for a budget PC game from 2006. XSEED did increase the game's resolution size and added widescreen support, but that's the most that they changed. Much of Origin's soundtrack consists of both original songs and rearrangements of music from the first two Ys games.

Origin definitely shines when in comes to extras. After completing the game with either character, a third character is unlocked, but I'll keep their identity a mystery.  There's also the standard boss rush, as well as Arena Mode, which pits players against 6 waves of enemies. SP can be earned in this game, which can be used to buy additional content, including Adol (only playable in the bonus modes) and extra versions of each character.

It's hard for me to recommend Origin as a first Ys game, simply because a lot of the game's storyline and setting depend on knowledge of the first two Ys games. While these are available on Steam (as Ys I & II Chronicles+), they don't play anything like any of the other games present on modern PCs. Origin is still a great game without the context, but somehow I feel like knowing about the references made in the earlier version makes the game feel more complete.

I've played other games by the company that made this game, notably The Legend of Heros: Trails in the Skys well. It even uses the same engine as said games.

One of my most favorite things with The Legend of Heros is the great story and writing. In terms of story and characters, this game is a complete 180. 

The main character, (there are 2 initially to chose from), in my case Yunica, has very little past and even less personality. She's forgettable and dull in almost all aspects. You can say the same for all the characters. Although most of the time you have no idea whom anyone is or why you should care.

The story is your standard there are some bad guys, doing bad things, and well, let's kick their butt. Well, I guess it's a little more complicated than that, but you are a girl on a mission.

The game mechanics revolve around a hack and slash style game. The mechanics are simple enough that anyone can wrap their heads around it. Perfectly fine to play on any game controller as well.

There is enough variety in the game to keep it interesting for the 11 or so hours it will take you to clear. You basically slash your way through an area. You find new armor, weapons, items as you wander. Occasionally you upgrade your weapons, skills, and armor. At the end of an area, you fight a boss. Lather rinse, and repeat.

The bosses have a fair variety of them. Most of them are not that difficult, but I did count 2 or 3 that might take you a couple tries to clear. The last few are shockingly easy.

If I have any major complaints there are a few areas of the game where you can get stuck looking for things. This could be a key, or you almost instantly die in an area, or can't figure out how to advance the story. If you cut these areas out there is probably less than 10 hours on a play-through.

Overall it's OK as a mindless hack and slash game to blow a few hours with. If you are looking for any kind of story, look elsewhere. I had higher hopes personally, and find it hard to recommend.
